Very moving, worth it for anyone who can appreciate what the pilots have had to go through to help open the north.
Amazing view from here! Definite must do and you can spend as little or as long as you want. Good place to take pictures!

It's easy to get to and doesn't require a lot of time. Street parking is available. There are a couple sets of stairs that you need to walk up to see the view. When I was here in the summer we had a spectacular view of the city and houseboats. We watched the bush planes come in

I spent the summer in Yellowknife and I found myself returning to this place time and time again just to take in the beautiful view. It's a wonderful monument honoring the Bush Pilots of the past and also today! It's located at the highest point of the entire town, closest to
Here you can view the town of Yellowknife, lakes! Very beautiful, Must go! We enjoy the lovely afternoon at the bush pilot's monument taking some pictures and fresh air!

This monument is easy to find. There is a wooden stair going up to the top of the hill. After that you will see the beautiful scenery of the bay and the surrounding area. I have tried to take a photo of the monument, unfortunately some selfish visitors took too long sitting by
Short hike up to a great viewpoint of all the water around Yellowknife, houseboats and horizon. Located in Old Town, which is a must go to for so many other reasons.
Although I am not sure if this is highest point in the old town, but climbing the stairs to get up there will give you a great view of the region and it is worth it!
Great views once you make it to the top of the stairs. There are places to stop and catch your breath if you are out of shape.
It will only take a minute or two to get to the top, but it is worth the climb to get the view. If you are walking around Old Town, it is definitely worth a visit.
We took a city tour from My Back Yard and stopped here to view the city. The view was spectacular and very peaceful. A must see !
Climb to the top of the monument for great views of the city. There are plaques for you to read. This is a free activity. you must be able to climb stairs.
Be sure to climb up & see the monument for the lovely 360 degree views of Back Bay, the town, and a little of the lake. Ere is a parking lot at the base of the stairs.

Great 360 view gives you your bearings. This is a must take picture spot and the monument and other interpretive signs give you a sense of where you are. If you can't climb several flights of stairs I don't think you can get there.
Go and check this place out! I was happy I didn't leave my camera in the car. The views of the houseboat community are amazing.
If you want a 360 view of Yellowknife, this is the place. Breathtaking view of Yellowknife Bay , the boat houses and bush planes. You can see all of the city.

I've been to YK countless times, but this was my first time to climb the steps up to the pilot's monument. It's a wonderful way to understand YK a little better- and truly appreciate the different neighbourhoods, landscapes, activities, and ways of life that can be experienced

The monument itself is quite plain, but since it's situated on the top of a rocky hill, it gives you a unique and unforgettable view of Yellowknife and Great Slave Lake. I would not have wanted to miss that! There are many colourful houseboats and small islands in view and

Located in the old part of town, there isn't much to see at this monument other than a beautiful vista of Yellowknife and surrounding area. If you are looking for a little walk and on your way to the Wild Cat Cafe, it's worth taking the stairs up and having a look around.
Beautiful views of Great Slave Lake and old town. Nice monument to bush pilots who opened the north.

You climb stairs to go up to the viewpoint. You can see quite a distance of the Great Slave Lake. Amazing how many houseboats are anchored to some of the islands & they stay there right through winter.

The day we went up to see the monument was so cold however once we got up there it was worth it and more. The views from the top were out of this world. We got up there in time to see the sunset. You can see Great Slave Lake right to downtown. It is one of my favorites. We hope
A lovely monument to bush pilots, and a great view of the city. Definitely worth seeing. Take your camera with you.
Great paneramic view of Yellowknife from here, you can see the city skyline and old town. A must see location
Great spot for Sunrise,sunset and to watch the Aurora..Its easy to find as you can see it from afar as its the highest point.You can part just below it and easy steps to the top.
Perfect to see the lakes during the day and the northern lights at night! Be careful on the steps !!
Easy walk up a hill and some steps to reach the top of this monument but worth it for the 360 deg vista over Yellowknife.
We went twice on the top to see the view. It has an amazing 360 degree view from the top. You can take the car half way through and then climb the stairs.
Its worth the climb upstairs to see the views!! Nothing on top except a perfect view of snow and frozen lakes. It gives you an idea of where things are as well.
This fitting memorial to the Bush Pilots is easy to find and offers a beautiful 360 viewpoint of Old Town and Lake - a must if visiting Yellowknife

A good place to visit for the views of the town and bay. Climbing the snow covered steps can be a bit of an adventure, but it doesn't take too long. A monument and plaque to the bush pilots who bolstered the economy of the Northwest, and good views. Worth the 10 minutes you'll

Even in -15C degree weather I'd recommend climbing up the stairs to the monument to check out the view. The viewing platforms at the top of this hill around the monument offer 360 degree views of lake and city. In our visit in February, you could see the ice landing strip for

I wasn't planning on going to the monument but had nothing else to do while waiting for a table -- so glad we went up there, it doesn't look high the but the views are worth the effort. It is more windy up there so be prepared at the bottom to bundle up at the top.
While visiting Yellowknife one of the highlights to see is the Bush Pilots Monument, standing high above the city it is very impressive

Pilots monument is a dedication for the pioneering bush pilots who blazed a trail to open the north. It is a great place to take a view of Yellowknife history and some beautiful scenery. The stairs to the monument take a bit to climb. There are restaurants nearby like the
Good view of the whole town at a very convenient location. Walking distance to local restaurant. Most importantly, we saw beautiful aurora right on it!
On a hill, you can see the beautiful view of the frozen lake and the snowy houses around you. Worth a go but really need to stay warm. Strong wind.
nothing too spectacular, but def. a place to visit when you are in the old town and want a view overlooking the old town and the lake area (since there is not much to see in the old town.)
Worth the climb to the top. You get rewarded with the most panoramic and beautiful view of Yellowknife and the frozen lakes. Dress warm if you're there in winter. It is windy and really cold.
I went there to see sun rise and I saw pink sky and sun came up from mountain that I could take the best shot photos
Its really worth travelling through town and making the short climb to the memorial. The views of Yellowknife and Great Slave Lake are spectacular.
A few stairs up and you have a beautiful view of Yellowknife and the lake. It's a little breezy up there so be better prepared than I was. Dress warm. I was there in December.
The monument is atop a hill, so you have a great view of the town and the Great Slave Lake. A must do for some panoramic photos.

We were staying in Old Town and this was recommended for both historical reasons and also a convenient way to spot an Aurora without heading out of town. We headed up around 9pm after peaking at the AuroraMax camera and sure enough there was a streak right across the sky.
It gives a great view of the lake and the town. Unfortunately, the abundant graffiti made it seem slightly dodgy. Easy stairs make the climb suitable for most people

Lots of stairs to climb but gives a good view of Yellowknife and especially where the float planes land. If you are there from Sept until end of May make sure you are properly bundled up and have mitts and hats. It can get windy and cold up there.
Great view of Yellowknife. Can see the city and house boats. Nice to sit and watch the float planes. Not easily accessible for people with wheelchairs.
If the weather is no good or cloudy in Yellowknife, it is impossible to watch Aurora. But if you rent a car from airport, you can spend one day in town area to have fun!

This is one of 'the' sights to see in Yellowknife. The monument is very simple. It's a wonderful tribute to the pilots who gave their lives in a high risk job to help develop Canada's northern territories. The big feature here is the incredible view of the city, lake areas,

It is a bit of a climb ( about 70 steps I was told by my grandson) but certainly the view is worth the effort! One can see the harbour with the houseboats, as well as the main section of the old town. Float planes were landing as we watched. It was interesting to read the
Can have a birds-eye view of the lake and the town from there. A bit tired to climb up to the top in snow but worth visiting.

My parents came for a visit to Yellowknife and we took them to the pilots monument. It is not too hard of a visit physically. It is a climb of approximately 70 steps. Once you reach the top the view is breathtaking. You can see the harbour with all the houseboats, as well as

We were interested to see this because our son had shown us a photo taken from it in winter conditions. The plaque was informative. Of course, we did not see the winter road to Dettah on the frozen lake.

There are some steps to get to the top, but it is probably the best bird-eye view of Yellowknife. There is the monument, but if you want to look like you hike up a mountain... there are exposed natural rocks just a few steps away for some cool pictures. Overall, easy to get to

There are a few steps leading up to this lookout so be warned that you will need to climb up. The 360 view you get of Yellowknife from above is fantastic. You can see the old town along with the new part of Yellowknife, and enjoy the planes coming in for a landing. If you have

The City of Yellowknife began around this Rock and how appropriate to put a monument to the pilots' that made living in the far north possible. This is not handicap accessible but there are a couple of "rest landings" on the way up. Pick a sunny day for the exceptional views.
There were many steps to climb to get to the top, but this is worth it for the view of the city and lake area. I saw float planes and houseboats from this spot.
A climb up about 100 stairs. The view is incredible. Well worth the walk. Resting stations on the way up.

Whether geocaching, taking photos, or getting a piece of history... This is a Yellowknife must. Take a photo of boats, eagles, house boats, sunsets or even sunrises. Read the various plaques or try to solve the nearby geocache. :) Welcome to our beautiful city.
Short walk up to the top. Was snowing at the time and the view was great. I really enjoyed the monument and would recommend travellers to Yellowknife to visit it.

Well worth the flight of stairs to see the 360 degree view of the back bays, houseboats and of course Yellowknife! Almost all the posted pics I see in the shops if Yellowknife are from this advantage! If you miss this spot you have missed Yellowknife!

This is a place you have to see. You can see all of the Old Town and most of the lake. All around you are gorgeous views whether it is the bay with boat houses or it is the scenic forest. This monument also gives you the ability to walk all around Old Town which is so worth

Always bring your camera. The short climb up the stairs affords a great vista where there is always lots going on all around you. The experience changes with the seasons and weather so it is always a good time to go. Bundle up if it is windy. Plenty of free parking is across the
Great view of old town Yellowknife. Very short climb up some stairs. Worth checking out if you're in town.

The monument sits high above Yellowknife and allows a wonderful view of the lake and the city. in the summer time you can see all he house boats and in the winter you can see the ice road and the ice castle. I go up every time I am in YK
While you are in Old Town it is a nice walk for a splendid view of the city. You are able to have a good 360 degree look of the area

What a beautiful place for this monument. We trekked up the hill in the middle of winter and we stayed here for a good hour just admiring the views, reading about the monument and enjoying the snow fall. We are also fans of Ice Lake Rebels so it was cool to see some of the

A short walk up the stairs gives you a great view of Yellowknife. Located in the old town you get a 360 degree view of the surrounds. Make sure you spend some time reading the plaques and wonder how did we ever really explore the north

If you visit or live in Yellowknife, you must make one visit to this spot. It is easy to get to. There is a parking lot at the base. An easy climb by stairs (careful at one flight, where the stair heights are shorter). This place will give you a very good look at

I loved being on top of the monument. It offers a wonderful 360° view encompassing the city, lakeshore, the colourful floating houses, etc. This is especially a must for first-time visitors and photographers. On the whole, it is calm other than the noise coming from the roads
Sixty three stairs but well worth the climb. Once you reach the top the view is amazing. You can see 360 degrees, Back Bay, Yellowknife Bay, Old town etc.
The monument is disappointing but the view of the area is well worth the climb up the steps. This is a must do activity.
walking up the stairs you feel like you can't wait to see the view, and when you finally get to the top, its jaw dropping. lots to look at

This is one of my favourite spots in Yellowknife. First because it pays tribute to the many bush pilots who helped open the north. Second because if is high enough to offer a spectacular view of the city and Great Slave Lake. There are quite a few stairs to climb so please
Really worth to go up because you can see the panarama! But keep warm! Make sure you come back before dark ...

This monument is at the highest spot around, and is easily accessible. The views in all directions are great, and if you are lucky you will see planes taking off and landing. Not to be missed if you are visiting Yellowknife.
The walk up isn't as bad as it looks. My husband is almost 70 and he managed ok. Best all round view of area. Especially the lake . Info signs show great history.
Must be able to climb stairs but the 360 degrees view is wonderful of Yellowknife...Old Town and New Town!
I highly recommend to stop by this place. You can have very clear view from the top(even if there is nothing much to see). Just cool down and take a picture!

Visited here a couple of times for fabulous views across all of Yellowknife. Fairly easy to get to via a wooden staircase but as with everywhere there is obviously some ice about so wear good footwear. Worth the climb to watch the town for a while. Take it in as part of a walk
Good views of the city and frozen lake, but nothing spectacular. You can just walk to it from the old town and get done with it in less than 30 min.
Amazing history and view of Latham Island and Back Bay. Clear view of new town and Old town. Loved it.

If you walk to the Old Town, you will not miss the Bush Pilot Monument as this is the highest point in the Old Town. It seems the stairs have recently been renovated and it is not difficult to walk up the stairs to the top, where you will have the panaramic view of the Old Town,
Parking lot on Ingraham road. An easy walk from anywhere in Old Town. A great 360 degree view of the area
the monument is on the highest point overlooking Yellowknife Bay. It is a must-visit place if you are in Yellowknife.

It was a little difficult for us to find our way up to Bush Pilot's Monument, but worth it to see a panoramic view of Yellowknife and we even ran into a group of ptarmigans on our way to the monument.

Stairs make it easy to get to the top, and the view is pretty good! You can look back at Yellowknife, see the houseboats, and basically anything else! It's the spot in the Knife to capture a good photo.
The view is spectacular! It is a climb but easy steps, not tiny straight up ones. Great pictures from the deck. Worth the time and the climb!
It was bitter cold with a slight wind when we visited but still enjoyed the view of the lake and the new town.
Gorgeous view, easy steps up, and worth taking the time to do. You'll get great pictures no matter what time of year.

We arrived in Yellowknife and went straight to Bullocks for lunch. Just up the hill was the Bush Pilots monument and decided to walk up. It is a beautiful spot on a high point over looking the bay. In January understand that it is snow covered and the bay and all water is

This is a great place to see Yellowknife, the Old Town and the Great Slave Lake. The place is small and easy to access. A few stairs too get you to the top. It has historical significance too highlighted on a number of plaques along the way to the top.
You can see the old town and downtown at the same time up above, I heard this is also a good place to watch out for Northern lights but never got a chance to do so.
a very good peak to look the whole old town and the lake and photo taking point. not a long walk the nearby attractions as well

Awesome views of the lake and city from this point. It was early January when we visited and we got a great view of the ice road to Dettah as well. Just be careful going up and down the access stairways when they are covered with snow.

It's really just a set of stairs, but the view from the top is a 360 panorama of Yellowknife and Great Slave Lake. This was our first stop when we arrived at sunset, a great way to start a visit to YK.

Bush Pilot's Monument is the highest point of Yellowknife and provides a great view of both old town and new town. We were there both during the day and night. A great place to view the city and the Great Slave lake.

It was pretty good. If you go see this go through old town too. It is a short walk up a staircase and you are there. Stairs can be slippery in the winter. The view isn't spectacular but it is worth seeing.

Easy to climb stairs with a few landings to stop and take in different views on the way up. Once at the top of the monument you have great views all around. Some interesting history of the area is written on the different brass plaques around the site as well. Definitely worth
Great panoramic view on old town, great slave lake and downtown I was there in Nov and everything was white. I recommend it!!
Beautiful shrine. Day or night the monument provides amazing views of Old Towne and surrounding area. Caught a glimpse of Aurora from here too!
This small hill top provides you with a fantastic view of the city and the lake. Remember to visit the small but well equipped fur shop situated at the intersection next to the hill.
A must seen in the city part of the history of the city and also a great view of downtown and the lake too!

As a life long resident of Yellowknife, no matter how many times I visit the Pilots Monument that it is loved anew each time I go there. My favorite time is at sunset or sun down or a nice day in winter or summer that permits us to see the plans landing and taking off. It is a
this monument offers the best view of the city, for photo lovers this is a must visit place, suggest to drive there otherwise it would be a 10 minutes uphill walk

this is a really impressive place. Not only do you see the monument, but you also have an incredible 360 degree view of Yelowknife and surroundings. The one downside: the stairs go on forever. Take your time if you have bad knees!
360 view of Yellowknife and the surrounding area. Stop in at Wild Cat Cafe for good fish and cold Canadian beer.
Different view between winter season and fall season. The best way to admire the Great Slave Lake. It is a very easy access walking distance from old town. Winter time will be a bit slippery
While in Yellowknife Old Town, its worth climbing the stairs to visit the monument. This location gives you a Super view, a great spot to take some pictures, Glad we did it.

When wandering around the Old Town area, take a few minutes to walk to the top of The Rock, which is the tallest hillside in the Old Town area. At the top, you can spend a few moments reading the plaque on the Pilot's Monument, which will make you realize how this wild frontier

I am a bed and breakfast small In owner. All my guests are recommended to check out he Pilots Monument. A wonderful place to see the city from day or night. Awesome place to experience the arrival and departure of float planes. Great place to view the ice road in winter and to

we visit the monument every time we have visitors from out of town. It is a favourite spot of mine. Unfortunately, there are a few steps to climb, not very accessible if you are not very fit or have strollers with you. But if you manage to get up, you get rewarded with the most

Long hike up the stairs but worth it to me. I was advised to go there when I stopped at the 60th Parallel visitor's center. I enjoy history and flying so of course it was of interest. The view was outstanding.
Neat hill and views. Great to climb after dinner and watch the sunset. Also helpful just to get oriented to the area a little bit. Views of the water and houseboats are neat.
Not really too much one can say about a monument, it is what it is. However this is definitely worth a visit just for the fabulous views it offers of the lakes and the town.
In OLD town area. High vantage point. Stairs to climb to top with excellent views of the water and Yellowknife. Also, a good view at night for Aurora.
We came here on our HHT. Definitely one of the BEST places to visit for free. Gorgeous view of the city! :)

This is a nice place to see on top of the rock and it gives a person a great view of the city and the Great Slave Lake. There is a decent stairway to the top and that really helped me get to the top of the rock because my legs are not as good as they used to be.
The Pilot's monument enables you to enjoy an amazing perspective of YK. With 360 views to the new town and across to Jollife island it is a great place for Aurora watching and also the evening sun.
A great place to get your first birds-eye view of Yellowknife! Lots of stairs, but well worth the climb!
Excellent view of the city when you get to the very top. It's breath taking and best of all it is free. Good orientation of where you are.

This monument is at the geographic high point of Old Town Yellowknife. It's an easy walk up well-maintained wooden steps to the summit of a rocky knob situated midway between Bullock's and the Wildcat Café (see restaurants). Good views out across the lake and overlooking the

This is one of the "must see" places in Yellowknife, both as an historic site and also for the view of the City and surrounding areas. The houseboats on Great Slave Lake are clearly visible from here. There is parking at the foot of a good, wide wooden staircase, which is a
Great view of Yellowknife - we even got to watch float planes land and take off near by!...several steps/stairs to get up there..
Nice walk up to a great vista view of old town, back/houseboat bays, and downtown. Panoramic and good for photos. Near to Bullocks and Wildcat, both great eats. ENjoy

Well worth the climb to the top. The views from the top are great in all 4 directions. Watch out for broken glass among the rocks. This offers a great view of the old town and the new parts of Yellowknife.
A good view of the city available from this point which also gives a good view of the harbour. You can also enjoy some fresh air
It took walking up a few steps at the monument but we were richly rewarded by a gorgeous view of the lake and the houseboats. I'd have loved to stayed and had a picnic!!
Sitting above a small hill, however it has stairs that would take you to the top. The view from here is also amazing. If you are doing old town, make this a stop

The monument is perched atop a large rock in the Old Town. It provides great panoramic views of the city and the surrounding area. Well worth the short climb up some well-maintained wooden stairs for the view.

It is the best monument in the city and the top for the surrounding at the old town. The design is simple in the shape of a paper plane that everyone could make in the childhood. It makes us to memorize the courage of human in the new frontier during their era. Easily to find
Go here early in your visit to Yellowknife to get an excellent view of the city and the city layout. . worth it. . free!
You simply can't visit Yellowknife without climbing to the top of this hill to see the incredible view. It's a 360° View of the lake and Yellowknife

The Bush Pilot's Monument is a simple monument atop a six story high rock in Yellowknife old town that pays homage to the gutsy bush pilots who opened up the NWT. There are well maintained stairs from Ingraham Drive that make the climb fairly easy. While the monument itself is

sights.name: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre

text.wiki:
Yellowknife (; Dogrib: Sǫǫ̀mbak’è) is the capital, only city, and largest community in the Northwest Territories, Canada. It is on the northern shore of Great Slave Lake, about 400 km (250 mi) south of the Arctic Circle, on the west side of Yellowknife Bay near the outlet of the Yellowknife River.
Yellowknife and its surrounding water bodies were named after a local Dene tribe at one time known as the "Copper Indians" or "Yellowknife Indians", today incorporated as the Yellowknives Dene First Nation, who traded tools made from copper deposits near the Arctic Coast. Its population, which is ethnically mixed, was 19,569 per the 2016 Canadian Census. Of the eleven official languages of the Northwest Territories, five are spoken in significant numbers in Yellowknife: Dene Suline, Dogrib, South and North Slavey, English, and French. In the Dogrib language, the city is known as Sǫ̀mbak'è (Som-ba Kay) ("where the money is"). Modern Yellowknives members can be found in the adjoining, primarily Indigenous communities of Ndilǫ and Dettah.
The Yellowknife settlement is considered to have been founded in 1934, after gold was found in the area, although commercial activity in the present-day waterfront area did not begin until 1936. Yellowknife quickly became the centre of economic activity in the NWT, and was named the capital of the Northwest Territories in 1967. As gold production began to wane, Yellowknife shifted from being a mining town to a centre of government services in the 1980s. However, with the discovery of diamonds north of the city in 1991, this shift began to reverse. In recent years, tourism, transportation, and communications have also emerged as significant Yellowknife industries.


== History ==

Traditionally, First Nations people of the Yellowknives Dene culture occupied this region. By the 1930s, they had a settlement on a point of land on the east side of Yellowknife Bay, Dettah. The current municipal area of Yellowknife was occupied by prospectors who ventured into the region in the mid-1930s.A Klondike-bound prospector, E.A. Blakeney, made the first discovery of gold in the Yellowknife Bay area in 1898. The discovery was viewed as unimportant in those days because of the Klondike Gold Rush and because Great Slave Lake was too far away to attract attention.In the late 1920s, aircraft were first used to explore Canada's Arctic regions. Samples of uranium and silver were uncovered at Great Bear Lake in the early 1930s, and prospectors began fanning out to find additional metals. In 1933 two prospectors, Herb Dixon and Johnny Baker, canoed down the Yellowknife River from Great Bear Lake to survey for possible mineral deposits. They found gold samples at Quyta Lake, about 30 kilometres (19 mi) up the Yellowknife River, and some additional samples at Homer Lake.

The following year, Johnny Baker returned as part of a larger crew to develop the previous gold finds and search for more. Gold was found on the east side of Yellowknife Bay in 1934 and the short-lived Burwash Mine was developed. When government geologists uncovered gold in more favourable geology on the west side of Yellowknife Bay in the fall of 1935, a small staking rush occurred. From 1935 to 1937, one prospector and trapper named Winslow C. Ranney staked in the area between David Lake and Rater Lake with few commercial results. The nearby hill known as Ranney Hill is his namesake and a popular hiking destination today. Con Mine was the most impressive gold deposit and its development created the excitement that led to the first settlement of Yellowknife in 1936–1937. Some of the first businesses were Corona Inn, Weaver & Devore Trading, Yellowknife Supplies and post office, and The Wildcat Cafe. Con Mine entered production on 5 September 1938. Yellowknife boomed in the summer of 1938 and many new businesses were established, including the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Hudson's Bay Company, Vic Ingraham's first hotel, Sutherland's Drug Store, and a pool hall.
The population of Yellowknife quickly grew to 1,000 by 1940, and by 1942, five gold mines were in production in the Yellowknife region. However, by 1944, gold production had ground to a halt as men were needed for the war effort. An exploration program at the Giant Mine property on the north end of town had suggested a sizable gold deposit in 1944. This new find resulted in a massive post-war staking rush to Yellowknife. It also resulted in new discoveries at the Con Mine, greatly extending the life of the mine. The Yellowknife townsite expanded from the Old Town waterfront, and the new townsite was established during 1945–1946. The Discovery Mine, with its own townsite, operated 81 kilometres (50 mi) to the north-northeast of Yellowknife from 1950 to 1969.

Between 1939 and 1953, Yellowknife was controlled by the Northern Affairs department (now Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada) of the Government of Canada. A small council, partially elected and partially appointed, made decisions. By 1953, Yellowknife had grown so much that it was made a municipality, with its own council and town hall. The first mayor of Yellowknife was Jock McNiven. In September 1967, Yellowknife officially became the capital of the Northwest Territories. This important new status sparked what has been coined as the third boom in Yellowknife. New sub-divisions were established to house an influx of government workers.In 1978 the Soviet nuclear-powered satellite Kosmos 954 crashed to Earth near Yellowknife. There were no known casualties, although a small quantity of radioactive nuclear fuel was released into the environment, and Operation Morning Light—an attempt to retrieve it—was only partially successful.A new mining rush and fourth building boom for Yellowknife began with the discovery of diamonds 300 kilometres (190 mi) north of the city in 1991. The last of the gold mines in Yellowknife closed in 2004. Today, Yellowknife is primarily a government town and a service centre for the diamond mines. On 1 April 1999, its purview as capital of the NWT was reduced when the territory of Nunavut was split from the NWT. As a result, jurisdiction for that region of Canada was transferred to the new capital city of Iqaluit. Consequently, Yellowknife lost its standing as the Canadian capital city with the smallest population.


== Geography ==

Yellowknife is on the Canadian Shield, which was scoured down to rock during the last ice age. The surrounding landscape is very rocky and slightly rolling, with many small lakes in addition to the larger Great Slave Lake. Trees such as spruce and birch are abundant in the area, as are smaller bushes, but there are also many areas of relatively bare rock with lichen. Yellowknife's high latitude causes a large variation between day and night. Daylight hours range from five hours of daylight in December to 20 hours in June. Twilight lasts all night from late May to mid-July.


=== Climate ===

Yellowknife has a continental subarctic climate (Köppen: Dfc). Although winter is predominantly polar, rapid heat waves emerge at the summit of summer due to the immense path south. The city averages less than 300 millimetres (12 in) of precipitation annually, as it lies in the rain shadow of mountain ranges to the west. Due to its location on Great Slave Lake, Yellowknife has a frost-free growing season that averages slightly over 100 days. In an occasional year, the first fall frost does not come until October. Most of the limited precipitation falls between June and October, with April being the driest month of the year and August having the most rainfall. Snow that falls in winter accumulates on the ground until the spring thaw.
Yellowknife experiences very cold winters and mild to warm summers. The average temperature in January is around −26 °C (−15 °F) and 17 °C (63 °F) in July. According to Environment Canada, Yellowknife has the sunniest summer in the country, averaging 1,034 hours from June to August. The lowest temperature ever recorded in Yellowknife was −51.2 °C (−60 °F) on 31 January 1947, and the highest was 32.5 °C (90.5 °F) on 16 July 1989. Yellowknife averages 2256.5 hours of bright sunshine per year or 43.5% of possible daylight hours, ranging from a low of 15.4% in December to a high of 63.0% in June. Due to its warm summer temperatures, Yellowknife is well below the Arctic tree line in stark contrast to areas further east in Canada on similar parallels.
In 2014, Environment Canada ranked Yellowknife as having the coldest winter and longest snow cover season of any city in Canada, while also experiencing the sunniest spring and summer of any city in Canada.


=== Cityscape ===

Yellowknife, like most other urban centres, has distinct commercial, industrial, and residential areas. Frame Lake, Niven Lake, Range Lake, and Old Town are the residential sectors, with some of the population living in high-rises in the downtown core. Niven Lake is the only area under active development and expansion. Downtown Yellowknife is home to most of the city's commercial activity, though some retail does exist in Range Lake. Industrial activity is limited to the Kam Lake and airport subdivisions.


==== Houseboats ====
Jolliffe Island sits in Yellowknife Bay and is public land under the jurisdiction of the City of Yellowknife after a land purchase when Imperial Oil vacated the site. The island is surrounded by a community of houseboats, where people have been living off the grid since 1978. Their relationship with the city is complex and often strained as the houseboats are popular with sightseers, but at the same time their residents live outside of the city's tax jurisdiction while still using city services, leading to lawsuits and tensions with the City of Yellowknife.


== Government ==

Yellowknife has a municipal government system and is governed by the Yellowknife City Council, which consists of an elected mayor and eight councillors. The Government of the Northwest Territories delegates powers to the municipality through legislative acts and regulations. Council meetings are held in the Council Chambers at City Hall on the second and fourth Monday of each month, and are open to the public. Municipal elections are held every three years. The current mayor of Yellowknife is Rebecca Alty, who succeeded Mark Heyck in 2018. Alty was elected 16 October 2018 and was sworn in 5 November.Yellowknife is represented in the territorial government by seven of the 19 Members of the Legislative Assembly of the Northwest Territories (MLAs). These MLAs are elected every four years and sit in the Northwest Territories Legislative Building, located in Yellowknife. The MLAs elect the Speaker of the House as well as six Cabinet Ministers and the Premier, which forms the cabinet. In addition, a Commissioner is appointed by the Federal Government to fulfil a similar role to that of the Lieutenant Governor. The Northwest Territories is one of only two federal, provincial or territorial jurisdictions in Canada that operate under a consensus system of government.The Northwest Territories is in the federal electoral riding of Northwest Territories and has one Member of Parliament, Michael McLeod, and one Senator, Margaret Dawn Anderson. Yellowknife is home to seven of the 19 electoral districts in the Northwest Territories, the Frame Lake, Great Slave, Kam Lake, Range Lake, Yellowknife Centre, Yellowknife North and Yellowknife South ridings.


== Economy ==

As the largest city in the Northwest Territories, Yellowknife is the hub for mining, industry, transportation, communications, education, health, tourism, commerce, and government activity in the territory. Historically, Yellowknife's economic growth came from gold mining, and later government; however, because of falling gold prices and increased operating costs, the final gold mine closed in 2004, marking a turning point for Yellowknife's economy.After a downturn in the 1990s during the closure of the gold mines and the downsizing of the government workforce in 1999, Yellowknife's economy has recovered, largely because of the diamond boom; the Ekati Diamond Mine, owned and operated by BHP Billiton (sold to Dominion Diamond Corporation in 2013), opened in 1998. A second mine, Diavik Diamond Mine, began production in 2003. Production from the two operating mines in 2004 was 12,618,000 carats (2,523.6 kg; 5,563.6 lb), valued at over C$2.1 billion. This ranked Canada third in world diamond production by value, and sixth by weight. A third mine, the De Beers owned Snap Lake Diamond Mine, received final approval and funding in 2005 and went into production in 2007. De Beers also applied in 2005 for a permit to open the Gahcho Kue Diamond Mine Project on the property formerly known as Kennady Lake. The mine was officially opened on September 20, 2016 and began commercial production in March 2017. As well, growth and expansion in natural gas development and exploration sectors has contributed to this growth. Economic growth in the Northwest Territories was 10.6% in 2003.

The major employers in Yellowknife include the Territorial Government, the Federal Government, Diavik Diamond Mines, Dominion Diamonds, DeBeers Canada, First Air, NorthwesTel, RTL Robinson Trucking, and the City of Yellowknife. Government employment accounts for 7,644 jobs, a large percentage of those in Yellowknife.
During winter, the Tibbitt to Contwoyto Winter Road is opened for semi-trailer truck traffic to take supplies from Yellowknife north to various mines located in the Northwest Territories and Nunavut. This ice road is usually open from the end of January through late March or early April, and Yellowknife becomes the dispatch point for the large number of truck drivers that come north to drive on the ice roads. During the 2007 ice road season, several drivers were featured on the History Channel TV series Ice Road Truckers.
Tourism is the largest renewable industry in the NWT and Yellowknife is the main entry point for visitors. Many tourists come to experience the Northern climate and traditional lifestyle, as well as to see the aurora. In 2004–2005, visitors to the territory spent C$100.5 million.

The City of Yellowknife raises 50% of its operating revenue through property taxation. Both Yellowknife Education District No. 1 and Yellowknife Catholic School Board also raise a portion of their operating revenue through property taxation. Property taxes in Yellowknife are calculated through property assessment and the municipal and education mill rates. Mill rates in 2005 were 13.84 (residential) and 19.87 (commercial).Canadian North, a regional airline, was headquartered in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Tower in downtown. The airline announced that when its lease was to expire in the end of August 2013, the airline will vacate the office and move it and 20 employees out of Yellowknife. The airline is now headquartered in Calgary.


=== Former regional mines ===

Yellowknife was originally established as a supply centre for numerous gold mines operating in the region in the late 1930s and early 1940s. The following is a list of the major mines, all of which are now closed. There were also tungsten, tantalum and uranium mines in the vicinity. Most mines in the Yellowknife area are within the Kam Group, a part of the Yellowknife greenstone belt.


== Infrastructure ==


=== Emergency services ===

Policing in Yellowknife is provided by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP); Yellowknife is the headquarters for G Division, and houses more than 30 officers.
The City of Yellowknife Municipal Enforcement Division (MED) is responsible for municipal bylaw infractions and traffic infractions (within city limits). The Yellowknife Fire Department handles the city's fire, ambulance, rescue, and hazardous materials responses. A point of debate in recent years has been the implementation of 911 services in Yellowknife (currently one may now dial 911) through a partnership with five other Northwest Territories communities; the cost of installation is currently estimated at around $1 million a year. There have been a number of incidents where emergency services have been either misdirected, or improperly dispatched. Health services are provided through the local Stanton Territorial Hospital. The Yellowknife Primary Care Centre has a broad range of practitioners including physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, counsellors, dietitians and more. Services provided at the Yellowknife Primary Care Centre include mental health, diabetes education, diagnostic imaging, psychiatry and some home care services.


=== Utilities and services ===


==== Communications ====
Yellowknife's telephone services were established in 1947 by the independent Yellowknife Telephone Company, owned by investors mostly within the community. The system was sold at the end of 1963 to Canadian National Telecommunications, now Northwestel. Northwestel also provides manual mobile telephone service on VHF frequencies, and by the 1990s also provided cellular services that were later transferred to Bell Mobility. In 2008, northern-based company Ice Wireless entered the market in Yellowknife, providing digital cellular products and services.
Yellowknife's television services, in addition to over-the-air transmission begun in 1967, included the Mackenzie Media cable television system placed in service 1 September 1972, which was sold to Northwestel in late 1995.


==== Electricity ====

Electricity is provided to Yellowknife by Northland Utilities, serving 6,350 residential and 800 commercial customers. Yellowknife operates almost entirely on hydroelectricity from the Snare-Bluefish systems, provided by the Northwest Territories Power Corporation (NTPC). NTPC's local production capacity is 67.9 megawatts, 30.89 MW from 10 generators at the Jackfish Diesel Plant, 28.8 MW from Snare Lake, and 7.5 MW from Miramar Bluefish.


==== Solid waste services ====
Residential garbage removal is through a user pay system, in which residents are allowed three 77 litres (17 imp gal; 20 US gal) garbage bags per week; any additional bags must have a purchased tag. The City of Yellowknife Solid Waste Management Facility is located on the Ingraham Trail (Highway 4) 2 kilometres (1.2 mi) north of the city; salvaging is encouraged, and the dump is infamous for the number of still useful items often found in it.


==== Water and sewage treatment ====
The City of Yellowknife provides pressurized potable water throughout the majority of the city, and has a network of gravity-fed sewage lines; trucked water and sewage is provided in areas not serviced by piped infrastructure. Sewage, with the aid of lift stations, is pumped to a series of lakes, referred to as Fiddler's Lake Lagoon, where it is held and allowed to naturally decompose. Water is obtained from the Yellowknife River and is disinfected with chlorine and liquid fluoride is added, but is not otherwise filtered or treated.


=== Transportation ===

Yellowknife, while isolated geographically, has a modern transportation system. The Yellowknife Airport is the busiest airport in northern Canada, having 70,699 aircraft movements in 2007 and handling over 400,000 passengers and 30,000 tonnes of cargo yearly. It has two asphalt runways, one 7,500 feet (2,300 m) strip and another of 5,000 feet (1,500 m); while the Yellowknife Airport is classified as an airport of entry by Nav Canada and is staffed by the Canada Border Services Agency, it is certified for general aviation aircraft only. The Yellowknife airport is designated by the Royal Canadian Air Force (RCAF) as a forward operating location for the CF-18 Hornet. Despite its shorter runways, the airport can still accommodate 747s and other wide-body aircraft for emergency landings. Air traffic control services, Instrument landing system (Category 1), and radar services are provided by Nav Canada.
Yellowknife Transit is the public transportation agency in the city, and is the only transit system in the Northwest Territories.Road construction in Yellowknife is often a challenge due to the presence of permafrost which requires that roads generally be regraded and resurfaced every 10 to 20 years. Most roads in Yellowknife are paved and road width varies from 9 to 13.5 metres (30 to 44 ft). Winter snow removal is done on a regular schedule by the City of Yellowknife public works department. Speed limits are 45 kilometres per hour (28 mph) on most roads, 30 kilometres per hour (19 mph) in school zones, and 70 kilometres per hour (43 mph) on highways. School zones and playground zones are in effect 24 hours per day 7 days per week. The highway system in the NWT is maintained by the Government of the Northwest Territories. Highway 4 (Ingraham Trail) and Highway 3 (Yellowknife Highway) both run through Yellowknife and are all-weather roads. One well-known, almost infamous, road in Yellowknife is Ragged Ass Road, after which Tom Cochrane named an album.
Until 2012, Yellowknife did not have a permanent road connection to the rest of Canada's highway network, as the Yellowknife Highway relied, depending on the season, on ferry service or an ice road to cross the Mackenzie River. With the completion of the Deh Cho Bridge, which officially opened on 30 November 2012, the city now has its first direct road connection to the rest of the country. One still-used ice road connects Yellowknife with the neighbouring community of Dettah, 6.5 kilometres (4.0 mi) to the southeast across an arm of Great Slave Lake; or a 27 kilometres (17 mi) drive via the Ingraham Trail.


== Demographics ==
As of the 2016 Census, there were 19,569 people and 7,130 households in the city. The population density was 185.5 inhabitants per square kilometre (480/sq mi). The 2016 Census found that 22.7% of residents identified as Indigenous. In 2017, the Government of the Northwest Territories reported that the population was 20,834 with an average yearly growth rate of 0.6% from 2007.In Yellowknife, the population is slightly younger at 34.6 than the average age for the rest of the NWT which is 34.9. However, the population is slightly disproportionate in terms of age distribution compared to the national average of 41.0. As of the 2016 figures, 13.9% of residents were 9 or under, 6.0% were from 10 to 14 years old, 13.1% were from 15 to 24, 34.1.2% were from 25 to 44, 22.0% were from 45 to 59, and 10.9% were 60 or older.

In 2016, the average household size was 2.7 and the majority of the population with children had either one or two. In 2015 the average income in the city was C$73,500, and the average income for a family was C$160,394, with 7.9% of all families earning less than $30,000. Minimum wage in Yellowknife and the NWT is C$13.46 (2018). Average household expenditures were C$125,783 in 2015. In 2016, the unemployment rate was at 5.9%; the employment rate for males was 80.1%, for females it was 75.2%.The crime rate in Yellowknife for 2016 was 46.7 (per 1,000 persons) for violent crimes, and 167.2 (per 1,000 persons) for property crimes. There were 299 births and 62 deaths in 2014.English was the mother tongue of 80.0% of residents and 3.2% spoke French. Of the nine official languages of the Northwest Territories 0.4% spoke Chipewyan (Dene); 0.1% spoke a Cree language; 0.1% spoke Gwich’in; 0.4% spoke Inuktitut; 0.1% spoke Inuinnaqtun or Inuvialuktun; 0.6% spoke North or South Slavey and 1.2% spoke Tłı̨chǫ (Dogrib). In total 3.0% of the population said that an Indigenous language was their mother tongue.Not including the 11 official languages there are over 70 different languages that Yellowknifers stated were their mother tongue. These include Indo-European languages (4.2%); Austronesian languages (3.9%); Indo-Iranian languages and Germanic languages (1.1% each); Sino-Tibetan languages and Chinese languages and Indo-Aryan languages (1.0% each). The five main individual languages are Tagalog (3.2%); Vietnamese (0.8%); German (0.6%); Cantonese and Spanish (0.5% each).Yellowknife is home to 695 recent immigrants (arriving between 2011 and 2016) who now make up 3.7% of the population. Of the recent immigrants 70.5% came from Asia; 15.1% from Africa and 7.2% from both the Americas and Europe. Of the recent immigrants 40.0% came from the Philippines, while 10.8% came from several African countries, 5.8% each from India, the United Kingdom and Vietnam, 4.3% from each of Japan and South Korea and 2.2% from IsraelYellowknife is primarily populated by European with a population of 11,680 (60.6% of total). The total Indigenous peoples population 4,375 representing 22.7% of the population (12.7% First Nations, 7.0% Métis), and 3.0% Inuit. Other ethnic groups include Filipino with 1,065 residents (5.5% of total), Black with 610 residents (3.2% of total) and South Asian with 510 residents (2.6% of total) with a total visible minority population of 3,230 (16.7% of total).In the 2001 Census almost 73% of residents identified as Christian while 24% said they had no religious affiliation.. For specific denominations Statistics Canada found that 36% of residents identified as Roman Catholic, 11% as Anglican, 10% for the United Church, about 2% each as Baptists, Lutheran, and Pentecostal, and more than 1% for The Salvation Army. There were also 135 Buddhists, 125 Muslims, and 15 Jews.


== Culture ==


=== Events ===

Folk on the Rocks is a local music festival that has been an annual occurrence since 1980. The event features a wide variety of musical acts; it is not limited to only Folk. In the past, it has drawn acts such as Buffy Sainte-Marie, the Trailer Park Boys, The Weakerthans, African Guitar Summit, Corb Lund, Fred Penner, Stan Rogers, Gord Downie, Tanya Tagaq, Dan Mangan, Sam Roberts Band, Sloan, The Strumbellas, Joel Plaskett, Ron Sexsmith and Hawksley Workman.
The Midnight Sun Golf Tournament, with games played through the city's well-lit summer nights, is also a significant cultural event.
During the winter, there is the Snowking Winter Festival, featuring a snow castle on Great Slave Lake which hosts a month of cultural activities
The Long John Jamboree, a new winter festival, took place 23–25 March 2012 on the frozen Yellowknife Bay next to the Snowking castle, in Yellowknife's Old Town neighbourhood. Events include an ice sculpture contest sponsored by De Beers Canada, cultural events like Dene hand games, games, live music, a beer garden, food vendors, skating rink, artist's market, and much more.
Yellowknife hosted the inaugural 1970 Arctic Winter Games, and has since hosted athletes and artists from circumpolar regions at the biennial multi-sport and multi-cultural event in 1984, 1990, 1998, and 2008 Arctic Winter Games.
The Old Town Ramble & Ride Festival started in 2006 and happens every summer for three days on the August long weekend. This free outdoor festival promotes local art, culture, music, artisans, dance, storytelling, workshops, tours, children's area and more.


=== Attractions ===

Some notable places to visit in Yellowknife include:

The Wildcat Cafe, which first opened in 1937. The popular restaurant still operates in its original building during the summer, which was moved to its current location after being saved from demolition in the late 1970s. The Wildcat Cafe has been renovated from 2011 to 2013, and during these times there were a few ups and downs to get the place ready for open. The City hosted a grand opening of the new Wildcat Cafe on 16 June 2013.
The Gold Range Bar, (also known as The Strange Range and listed in the circa 1989 phonebook as such) one of the oldest and most colourful drinking establishments in the Northwest Territories and featured in Elizabeth Hay's novel "Late Nights On Air" and Mordecai Richler's novel Solomon Gursky Was Here.
Downtown contains the Capital Area Park, a short but pleasant stroll by City Hall, the Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, the Legislature.
The Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre is a museum containing exhibits of the history and culture of Inuit, Inuvialuit, Dene, Métis and non-aboriginal peoples of the NWT. It's found just north of downtown on an attractive location overlooking Frame Lake.
Near the Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, the Northwest Territories Legislative Building houses the territory's legislative assembly.
The Northern Arts and Cultural Centre, which is located in Sir John Franklin High School and is the city's largest indoor stage for theatre and musical presentations.
Elon the Muskox (Elon Muskox), a mosaiculture horticultural living sculpture of a muskox exhibited in front of City Hall.Other notable attractions include the Ingraham Trail, local fishing lodges, bush plane tours, the unique architecture of Old Town with the Bush Pilots monument, and any of the numerous lakes surrounding Yellowknife, many of which include beaches.


==== Historical sites ====


== Media ==


=== Print ===
The Yellowknifer, published by Northern News Services, is the major newspaper serving Yellowknife, published twice weekly on Wednesday and Friday. Northern News Services also publishes Northwest Territories News/North every Monday, which serves the entire NWT. As well, there is L'Aquilon, a French language newspaper published weekly. Edge Magazine is also based in Yellowknife where it began it 2011 and covers arts, events, people, culture and economy around the City.
Two magazines are based in Yellowknife: Above&Beyond and Up Here, both offering northern-related news and lifestyle articles.


=== Radio ===


=== Television ===
No part of the Northwest Territories is designated as a mandatory market for digital television conversion; only CFYK-DT converted its main transmitter in Yellowknife to digital.
On 10 August 2012, NASA announced that the section of Mars where the Curiosity of the Mars Science Laboratory mission landed would be renamed Yellowknife, in recognition of the city of Yellowknife. Yellowknife is usually where scientists start geological mapping expeditions when researching the oldest known rocks in North America.

Very much worth a visit. This was probably the best museum of its kind I have been to. NIce cafe as well.

Excellent source to understand Aboriginals way of life. Display of Moose-skin boat, minerals and primitive tools are highlights.

Small center PACKED with history and culture of the area. Go on the first day in Yellowknife. Do not miss this!
Place to learn about Yellowknife. Well organized displays and info areas. Good photo opps inside and out!

Very well done. Lots of interesting exhibits covering all aspects of the area. Easy access from the town and very nice location. Good restaurant with local fare.

Well organized, plenty of interesting nice articles!!! So rich and alive!! Great for adults and children. We loved to chat to Mr. Blaine at the entrance of the museum! At the restaurant, we had perfect coffee and we wished we had time to have lunch there - next time for sure!!

Local view to its historical livelihood about Aboriginal culture, lots to see from this cosy museum, many interesting and aged items that we call recall from many years ago. We would always learn from the past and to improve for our future.
A wonderful, free museum that showcases some pretty neat stuff from the NWT. Right beside the government legislative building. A must do when visiting Yellowknife.

Very informative museum with the best cafe! I highly recommend taking a few hours out to visit. You won't regret it.This was the first place I ever visited in Yellowknife and i have visited it at least 3 times since. Oh and its free!

Highly recommend to go to this Museum. You will find a lot of history about the Northwest Territory. It's worth to spend time :)
Good for information and very good display, no admission required, building is well maintained and good to visit.

it's a nice museum / place to understand more the culture/history and wild lives of Nordic circle. it's located in a convenient location, no admission fee and most visitors enjoy the exhibits and it's precious to see the 1 first handmade google.

Nice exhibit of Yellowknife 's history, culture, people, n nature. We went there before tours viewing Buffalo, n hiking Cameron Fall, we found the information helpful and appreciated more of the visit .

Excellent museum, very interesting historical information. Spent about an hour and a half with a few friends. Staff very helpful. Had a great time!
This is a must for anyone visiting Yellowknife. They did an excellent job on the exhibit making it great for folks of all ages.

We brought our grandchildren here before heading up to Cunningham Inlet and stay at Arctic Watch Lodge. Thet had fun learning about the north and did not want to leave.

Great museum, many artefacts and history. Staff is great, take a moment to chat with them. Don't miss the Dene tree!

Really informative and interactive museum which shows you about the people, culture, history as well as arctic life. Extensive collection of exhibits. Good place to understand yellowknife. High quality for free admission exhibition.
Nice museum with lots of tidbits about Northern Canada's First Nation Peoples as well as Northern Canada in general.
Great place. Well worth checking out. Unfortunately I didn't get to the Heritage centre until my last day, so my time there was restricted by my flight. But i could have easily spent hours in there.
Fairly small. Very interesting. Excellent natural exhibits. Very realistic. Excellent restaurant for lunch. Not to missed

Great way to get an understanding what is out there if you mind the cold. I would prefer seeing the real thing tho but this place is pretty neat.

Great place to learn and see the cultures,history , and information about the North West Territories ,and the building is a Museums and Exhibits ,stay less hour ! very impressed .

We went here on our January trip to Yellowknife. It's lovely and has some great exhibits. Well worth a visit.

On a recent visit to Yellowknife we checked out this place and found it very informative and interesting, definitely a place to visit if you are in Yellowknife

It's such a special facility, and it's amazing that it remains free access. This place is a great way to spend an afternoon!

modern structure, suitable for family with children. Lot of historic items and animals spicimen. Ten minutes walking distance from town. While you wake up late since spending all night for watching northern light, this is a good place.

An excellent selection of Northern Artists, cultural collections, interactive play room for the kids.

They have alot of good information with a nice cafe to finish off. There taxidermy on the animals and background history the staff have done a terrific job with everything. A must see for all ages.

This territory museum has excellent, informative exhibits that give insight into the area - in terms of the mining, the native peoples, the geology and history.

In the archive they got the original mace of the legislative assembly. The legislative assembly's got the duplicate on display.

Beautiful exhibits that document and celebrate the Northwest Territories's history, cultures and fauna. A must!

I have always loved visiting this beautiful building...the architecture is stunning and the collections unique and there is fun stuff for the kids and there is a fantastic restaurant.

good introduction of local culture, recommend to go there for 1st day. layout is easy to follow and display is surprisingly good.
