text.wiki:
Google Street View was first introduced in the United States on May 25, 2007, and until November 26, 2008, featured camera icon markers, each representing at least one major city or area (such as a park), and usually the other nearby cities, towns, suburbs, and parks. Many areas that had coverage were represented by icons.


== Key additions ==

On May 25, 2007, Street View was announced.
On May 30, 2007, at the Where 2.0 Conference, Immersive Media was identified as the contractor that captured the imagery for four of the five cities initially mapped by Street View, using its patented dodecahedral camera array on a moving car. Immersive Media continued to do image capture for Street View until Google developed its own capability to do so. Since July 2007, Google has used imagery that belongs exclusively to Google.
On April 16, 2008, Street View was fully integrated into Google Earth 4.3.
On May 12, 2008, Google announced that it was testing face-blurring technology on its photos of the busy streets of Manhattan. The technology uses a computer algorithm to search Google's image database for faces and blurs them, according to John Hanke, director of Google Earth and Google Maps.
On June 10, 2008, two other features included in the update were an effective mask of the "Google Car" and the application of face-blurring technology on all photos, which effectively lowered the resolution across all photos, even the formerly impressive high resolution images of San Francisco. Also, many nearby metro areas were included, but they did not receive their own camera icons.
On July 2, 2008, Google Street View was introduced in France and Italy, providing the first service outside the United States and the debut of Google's new 4th Generation Cameras. On this day, 19 camera icons were added, mostly showing small towns and areas along the Tour de France route and part of northwestern Italy.
On August 4, 2008, 28 icons of major metropolitan areas of both Australia and Japan were added to Google Street View. Included in the update were approximately 40 new U.S. hub cities.
On November 26, 2008, the Street View button and all the camera icons were deleted. Instead of clicking the "Street View" button, this is now accessed using the "pegman" button in the left hand corner. When the "pegman" icon is dragged over the map blue polylines appear where Street View is available and a small window will show the current Street View. If this is dropped on the map the Street View opens and takes over the whole map window.
On December 1, 2008, New Zealand was added to Google Street View. Faces were blurred upon recommendation by the New Zealand Privacy Commission, but vehicle registration plates were not obscured.
On April 9, 2009, Street View became available with a full-screen option.
On June 5, 2009, Smart Navigation was introduced which allows users to navigate around the panoramas by double-clicking with their cursor on any place or object they want to see.
In mid-June 2010, Google added blue dots to its maps that display user-submitted images in all locations around the world, including land areas where Street View is not available and bodies of water. These images can be pulled up on the screen in the same manner as a Street View image with the pegman by dragging it onto the blue dot.
On October 30, 2012, Google announced that users could contribute to Street View by creating a panorama-like image from the Galaxy Nexus smartphone to share on Google Maps.
On February 14, 2013, Wii Street U was released for the Wii U.
On June 27, 2013, Google announced that users could contribute to Street View by creating a panorama-like image from the Galaxy non-Nexus smartphone to share on Google Maps.
On April 23, 2014, a new historical Street View option was introduced to new Google Maps. The date of panoramas can be selected from the timeline.
Starting in August 2017, Google allows users to create their own street view-like blue paths, for the connected photospheres that are sufficiently close to one another.

Below is a table showing the countries available on Street View and the year they were first added. Plain text indicates that a country has only views of certain businesses and/or tourist attractions.


=== Current coverage ===
Bold with an asterisk (*) indicates countries with public street view available


=== Future coverage ===
Below is list of the countries that do not currently have official coverage where Street View vehicles are currently driving, where Street View is officially planned, or have reported by media to be driving.
Public streets in Guernsey and India (Bangalore), as well more places in Germany were filmed but at this time the images are not online due to some privacy concerns.

trip: We rented cross country skis and boots for the day from Overlander Sports in Yellowknife and took a 5 minute taxi ride to the ski club. Overlander gave us a trail map- trails on site were well marked. There were both classic and skate trails since the club also has biathlon

google: Good way to get to know the local culture
trip: This was a great museum. I spent a few hours going through all of the exhibits and also ate brunch on the weekend here. The food is great (and not too expensive) and entry to the museum is free. The exhibits span quite a broad range from police to art to animals to Inuit culture

The museum was very interesting. My wife and I wondered around here for about 2 hours. Normally I do not visit museums in new towns as I expect them to be too boring but this one was worth the while. In addition, the cafe was very comfortable, the food was good and a

To my surprise, there is a museum in this little town. Free entry and you can understand more about the Inuit people, they have not many valuable displays but you would enjoy the exhibitions, with sound files and video.

Beautiful building that showcases territorial artists in some of the areas while highlighting the Innuit way of life, where the Aboriginal villages were located and how they traveled by canoe which could be dismantled and recycled into other uses. Interesting to visit a room

Beautiful small museum with brilliant restaurant. Great stories on Indigenous involvement in RCMP, the geology, fauna and animal life in the north. Q-Trip: A great start to your Yellowknife visit. Q-Trip: The graphic comic on the Mad Trapper is great. Q-Trip: Restaurant at #27
I enjoyed visiting this museum. We've learned a lot and everything is interesting! Saw different wild animals that never heard about it.

A wide variety of cultural and nature exhibits. My favorites were the muskrat exhibit and the Walt Humphries paintings. Very helpful staff, and we were there for the opening ceremony of the Naka Festival. Great programs!
I would highly recommend a trip to the museum. Wonderful historical pieces and very interesting displays. There is no charge for admission but donations are welcome. The cafe is also worth a visit.
Warm and cozy place with lots of research results. Good exhibition of life in subarctic life. The best-recommended place to visit other than the Aurora tour.
Open on Sunday's, free and warm - well done displays sharing the history of the area. Children’s play area and a small cafe open Monday thru Friday bfast and lunch

An amazing spot near the town centre. Lots of interesting displays and artifacts. We learned a lot about NWT history and wildlife. A few of the interactive exhibits didn’t function properly, but this didn’t take away from the impact of the centre. Highly recommended—a must see!
It was very nice to see all the items in the Museum. My family and I will be coming back here again very soon.
We loved the great displays and historical information on display. YK should be proud of this resource.

Added some culture to our visit to Yellowknife. The museum spoke to the history of the land, people, and cultures of the Territory. Donation to get in, a place to put your warm coat, and a nice easy stroll around the building.
The museum is small and can be covered in just over an hour. It is nice and shares a lot of history and culture of the area

We stayed across the street at Chateau Nova hotel so it was an easy and pretty walk to this well organized Centre. Free entry and you can make a donation at the door. The history of the area and it’s people is well told in the separate rooms. There is a separate children’s

We had planned a lot of outdoor activities in Yellowknife but the weather was too cold so this was the perfect place to spend the day. Unfortunately the cafe was closed, but we enjoyed the exhibitions and learned a lot. There is also an art gallery which is cool, but I didn't
This Heritage Centre is small but packed with a lot of interesting history of Yellowknife. Well worth a visit....and it was free.

The Heritage Centre has some really interesting displays of different elements of life in the NWT, the history and the wildlife. I spent an hour or two here checking out the displays, but i'm sure if you were to listen to and read everything it could occupy a half day. Admission

We visited the museum based on TA reviews. We were not disappointed. This museum has a surprising amount of local history packed into interesting exhibits. We happened to catch a docent led tour which added to our experience. Undoubtedly the best lunch in town.
I learned a lot of cultural facts and history from Yellowknife, and there is a restaurant where the staff is very nice.
You have to visit to get a great understanding of the surrounding people and places. Great displays....kudos to the museum director. Place to hang a jacket....good washrooms. Must see
Lots to learn here, very well organized and friendly staff. Great little restaurant to have a snack and coffee before you leave

There is a kid’s corner that is fun for young children. The museum is free and it has nice coffee! It’s a must-go if you are in town.
I enjoyed my visit here . Really good exhibits. The staff a friendly, and helpful. I went to look at the RCMP Special Constable exhibit. My late grandfather was a Special Constable.
The displays about northern life and history make this museum a must see. The cafe serves great food and has great service.

It has the displays divided into large rooms and areas so that you can spent time in each area reading and looking at the 3d displays . A lot of time was spent on detail to make the displays look as if you were outside in that area. There is a food area upstairs you can get

Had a great time learning about the history of the area. This is a must when visiting Yellowknife. Situated right on the lake!

The displays are visually appealing, the exhibits have brief descriptions, and the tour is easy to navigate.
We really enjoyed our visit here. We learned a lot about the history and settlement of NWT an d Yellowknife. It’s free, but goodwill donations help support them - very interesting place!

Don't miss this great museum that is within walking distance from central Yellowknife. We learned a lot about the culture and history of the indigenous communities. We even saw a raw diamond that had been to the space and back. Excellent exhibits and friendly professional
A must place to visit when in Yellowknife. You learn a lot about the history of Yellowknife and about the life of indigenous people of the North.

This was a nice short walk away from downtown and on a good weather day well worth the walk. The exhibits were well laid out, marked and easily accessible. The coffee shop was slow to respond during a busy time and should have had another Worker on. The food was reasonable, but
We went at the end of our stay but should have went at the beginning as would have understood much more about the Dene Nation and their culture as we travelled about.
A definite place to visit. The artifacts on display are rare and very well presented. Every visit to me is an experience.

Being from Winnipeg, I am familiar with some of the history of the area. For me the highlights were the Moose Hide Canoe and RCMP Special Constable exhibit.
Visited the museum and the front desk worker was very helpful. A great museum well done and fairly large. Don't miss it.
It may be free but it's worth SO much more than that. An absolutely beautiful museum with lots to see.
I would recommend this place to everyone who has at least a couple hours to kill. Very cool history of the city.

Good and detailed information about geography, economy, history & indigenous communities. Must see place. Walkable from Yellowknife City Hall (take the short walkway from behind the city hall to Museum)

Really well done and well worth several hours. They have a tremendous variety of human and natural history. The exhibits contain lots of really interesting information and artifacts. It's all great. The café is really nice, also. Entry is free, but they accept donations. I
Always a nice break from the downtown restaurants. Nice deserts and sandwiches. Friendly staff in relaxed setting.

Fun and interactive museum. Really gave of the lay of the land at the beginning of the trip. The cafe is out of this world! Everything was a win but the white fish with cilantro sauce was amazing and fresh! I recommend the museum and cafe! Wonderful staff, so friendly and
Excellent! Very professionally done, and the staff are friendly, knowledgeable and helpful. This is one of the “must sees” in Yellowknife.

I’ve been here a few times in the last couple of years and I learn something new every time! The exhibits are fantastic and show much of the northern history. The kids area is unique and gives them a real chance to use their imaginations!

We visited the museum Thursday night as it was open late. We covered the museum in a couple of hours. It’s quite interesting explaining the history of the area, the people and how commercialization began. If you have a couple of hours it is worth a visit.
I spent several hours at he Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Center, which was awesome! There is so much to see and learn, and their is no charge to view the displays!!! Loved it!
Beautiful building on edge of Frame Lake just few walking blocks from central Yellowknife. Great galleries learning about arctic, wildlife, fish, history, RCMP, and indigenous groups

Museum gives you a wonderful introduction to the animals found in the area. indigenous cultures of the area, and the early settlement history. Great exhibits. After touring the museum stop by the restaurant for a warm root vegetable salad or tandoori chicken. Can't beat the food.

Very interesting. And it’s free too! Make a donation though, it is well worth supporting this museum. We learned a lot about the history and heritage of the Northwest Territories. There was lots to look at and to read. And hands - on stuff for the younger set. As a visitor,

great place to learn about Yellowknife, how the aboriginal lived, what is northern territories, what cities are there, what difference in right do Aboriginal and Canadian have. Generally a great place to know some history of Northern Territories.
Learn about animals, rocks, minerals and gems, geological information, indigenous peoples, etc. In the NWT.
Great way to spend an hour or two. Great displays, very informative. There is a cafe but it was closed when we were there. It is free to get in

Very much worth a visit. This was probably the best museum of its kind I have been to. NIce cafe as well.

Excellent source to understand Aboriginals way of life. Display of Moose-skin boat, minerals and primitive tools are highlights.

Small center PACKED with history and culture of the area. Go on the first day in Yellowknife. Do not miss this!
Place to learn about Yellowknife. Well organized displays and info areas. Good photo opps inside and out!

Interesting displays for all ages. Displays on way up walkway are worth exploring. Make sure you go to the gallery beforie sampling the delicious apple walnut cake/pudding

Very well done. Lots of interesting exhibits covering all aspects of the area. Easy access from the town and very nice location. Good restaurant with local fare.

We are from Edmonton, hoping to see aurora in Yellowknife. Yellowknife museum is free and very informative. Lots of information about the history, the animal you can find here, and more. Highly recommended.

Well organized, plenty of interesting nice articles!!! So rich and alive!! Great for adults and children. We loved to chat to Mr. Blaine at the entrance of the museum! At the restaurant, we had perfect coffee and we wished we had time to have lunch there - next time for sure!!

The museum is really interesting even for people who usually pass by museums and it is free to enter. Lots of information on the way life was lived in this harsh environment. Good cafe open for lunch.

Local view to its historical livelihood about Aboriginal culture, lots to see from this cosy museum, many interesting and aged items that we call recall from many years ago. We would always learn from the past and to improve for our future.
A wonderful, free museum that showcases some pretty neat stuff from the NWT. Right beside the government legislative building. A must do when visiting Yellowknife.
It was a very cozy and nice museum that had lots of interesting information and history shown. Free to enter and closes pretty late, it is definitely a place to check out while in Yellowknife.

Very informative museum with the best cafe! I highly recommend taking a few hours out to visit. You won't regret it.This was the first place I ever visited in Yellowknife and i have visited it at least 3 times since. Oh and its free!

We did spend some time here while hanging around in town, its good place to visit and know more about the place about YellowKnife..
Highly recommend to go to this Museum. You will find a lot of history about the Northwest Territory. It's worth to spend time :)
Good for information and very good display, no admission required, building is well maintained and good to visit.

it's a nice museum / place to understand more the culture/history and wild lives of Nordic circle. it's located in a convenient location, no admission fee and most visitors enjoy the exhibits and it's precious to see the 1 first handmade google.

Nice exhibit of Yellowknife 's history, culture, people, n nature. We went there before tours viewing Buffalo, n hiking Cameron Fall, we found the information helpful and appreciated more of the visit .
Nice displays of wildlife and history of the Northwest Territories. Be sure to go next door to the capital building and take the tour there which is very very good.

This is a must for anyone visiting Yellowknife. They did an excellent job on the exhibit making it great for folks of all ages.

We brought our grandchildren here before heading up to Cunningham Inlet and stay at Arctic Watch Lodge. Thet had fun learning about the north and did not want to leave.

Great museum, many artefacts and history. Staff is great, take a moment to chat with them. Don't miss the Dene tree!
Great museum! Pleased to learn about special constables (RCMP); northern clothing and Phillipinos! Lovely building and grounds. Donations only for entrance fee but you'll want to make one!

I took my dad to the Centre for Father's Day. Great exhibits. A very helpful security officer offered a wheel chair for us to use.

Great place to spend on a rainy/cold day. There are about 3-5 display rooms and you can spend hours here. There is so much to see and learn, plan for a few hours here. And it is good for children too. Would return again because they change there displays.
Had a very enlightening visit to the Museum. Learned a lot about the history as well as native culture. Great for children of all ages.

Really informative and interactive museum which shows you about the people, culture, history as well as arctic life. Extensive collection of exhibits. Good place to understand yellowknife. High quality for free admission exhibition.
Nice museum with lots of tidbits about Northern Canada's First Nation Peoples as well as Northern Canada in general.
Great place. Well worth checking out. Unfortunately I didn't get to the Heritage centre until my last day, so my time there was restricted by my flight. But i could have easily spent hours in there.
Fairly small. Very interesting. Excellent natural exhibits. Very realistic. Excellent restaurant for lunch. Not to missed

Great place to learn and see the cultures,history , and information about the North West Territories ,and the building is a Museums and Exhibits ,stay less hour ! very impressed .

We went here on our January trip to Yellowknife. It's lovely and has some great exhibits. Well worth a visit.
A place to understand the history of Yellowknife. It is in the town center, very easy to reach. The scenery around is also good.
On a recent visit to Yellowknife we checked out this place and found it very informative and interesting, definitely a place to visit if you are in Yellowknife

It's such a special facility, and it's amazing that it remains free access. This place is a great way to spend an afternoon!

My 2 children are very excited and happy when they are trying to finish the treasure hunt paper prepared by the centre... After they complete the paper they have been rewarded a badge... They were so happy with this...
A must see on your visit. Well designed and curated exhibits with interesting descriptions. Displays include full size bison, caribou, polar bear, etc. There is a fun children's play area.
Highly recommend spending half day here. Beautiful and informative! Didnt know much about Yellowknife before attending the centre, learned so much about its history!

As there is limited activities in daytime yellowknife. This will be a very good relaxing place to visit, the center have many interesting items to explore if you have time. It can spend you easily an hour or more being there. Seats are available too if you just want to escape

modern structure, suitable for family with children. Lot of historic items and animals spicimen. Ten minutes walking distance from town. While you wake up late since spending all night for watching northern light, this is a good place.

It's a really interesting place to go and Thursdays they close late and the entrance is free! they do have all kinds of events though out the year
An excellent selection of Northern Artists, cultural collections, interactive play room for the kids.

Add my knowledge about Canada, not just the metropolitan way of life in the cities. A guided tour of the Legislative Assembly building furthered my knowledge about modern North Canada. Highly recommend to have lunch as well as teatime at the museum cafe.
They have alot of good information with a nice cafe to finish off. There taxidermy on the animals and background history the staff have done a terrific job with everything. A must see for all ages.

Really nice building that houses the tourist information temporarily, great displays of how life was in the early settling years, many animal displays and its FREE. Great job Yellowknife!

Very well done displays of northern Canadian history and nature. Beautiful photographic works as well. No admission fee, donations only. Very tasty food in the museum restaurant also
In the archive they got the original mace of the legislative assembly. The legislative assembly's got the duplicate on display.
Good cafe and nice exhibits. Family friendly and accessible to all. Exhibits rotate and are a nice introduction into the culture of Yellowknife.

Beautiful exhibits that document and celebrate the Northwest Territories's history, cultures and fauna. A must!

Great layout, nice pacing, variety of art, history and artifacts. Staff not all that present and if there are tours either audio or in person they were not promoted. Saw no sense of events happening. Not a lot of interactive exhibits although the northern lights one was fun.

I didn't expect it to be this great for such a small town. It it very informative and interesting. Don't miss it.

I have always loved visiting this beautiful building...the architecture is stunning and the collections unique and there is fun stuff for the kids and there is a fantastic restaurant.

Took my family here to eat on a number of occasions. We have always found the atmosphere great, the staff friendly, and the food delicious. Would highly recommend this restaurant to any tourist visiting the Prince of Wales Museum.
Wonderful displays. A great place to bring the kids to play, and whittle some time away. And its FREE!!

I had a great time perusing the Centre. I thought I would just spend a hour there but I ended up spending way more time as I found it very interesting! It is full of interactive activities, audio and video displays.It is suitable for people of all ages! It is also free but

Museum is free. Shows clothes, boots, etc., made by various aboriginal groups in area which was interesting but then became repetitive. Showed all the various rare earths and minerals that went into computers and which came from Yellowknife area which was interesting. Of
This is a beautiful museum is free for visitors. I personally like the display of animals. it is accessible from downtown.
Quite hard to find, but well worth persevering. This museum has displays of the animals and people of the Northwest Territory. Also, the cafe is excellentr!

Looking for something to do on down time and saw this on Trip Advisor. Exhibits are very nicely laid out. I love the fact that there are specific rooms for most of the displays. Loads of information on plaques, large displays and audio information. I am from Canada but

I went there expecting to be less than an hour but I was almost 3 hours. It is really well laid out and gives a real insight as to how the NWT came to exist and the hardships the earlier settlers experienced. This to me was time extremely well spent. By the way, the restaurant

The exhibits are very well laid out and gave us lots of information on the aboriginal people of the north. The story and video of the moose hide canoe was amazing. It was really an eye opener to be able to look at how the people and animals survive and thrive in such harsh

I was greeted by one of the receptionists, who was enthusiastic about telling me what kind of exhibits were on at the time, their hours, and where to start. A map of the centre was provided, and help got me oriented. Definitely worth the donation to learn all sorts of things
Beautifully designed building with interesting and informative exhibits - be sure to make time for lunch or a snack at the Museum Cafe.
The Mayors of Yellowknife and of Edmonton hosted a luncheon the other day at the museum cafe. Wonderful location, great room, great food. I'm looking for a reason to host my own event there.
good introduction of local culture, recommend to go there for 1st day. layout is easy to follow and display is surprisingly good.

Surprisingly extensive presentations, lots to see and reflect on. We caught the free tour, guide was very informative, a bit of a raconteur. Fun kids area with lots of play and dress up opportunities. Finish up with a snack or meal at the Museum Cafe.

I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this museum. We went on our last day in Yellowknife to escape the -15C cold outside. This museum has a good amount of exhibits to spend an hour or more but its not too overwhelming. There is a good balance of exhibits on the land,
Informative exhibits on history, culture, and nature, set up beautifully so you can have a quick overview or really dive in and learn a lot. Highly recommended, you will learn and see new things.

It was a great place to visit and understand more about the aboriginal cultures. specially the two rooms of animals (with a polar bear and a musk) and the room regarding the culture are of great interest. Totally recommended. The museum is open til 9 pm on thursdays and the
Must do whilst in Yellowknife. Provides you with a good background on Yellowknife and it's heritage. A number of very interesting displays . Great cafe for coffee or a light lunch.
This indeed is a museum highlighting the north. Have a great kids play area on the main floor. The "cafe" is highly spoken of in the local area. Unfortunately is not open on Sunday(cafe).

This was a great museum with lots of things to see. I spent a couple hours here and didn't even get to all the exhibits. The best part of it all was that there is no entrance fee! I love that with museums because then you can come and go as you please and don't feel like you
We were lucky to joined in a morning tour guild, the gentleman was really informative and we learnt so much more NWT history and geographic knowledge from him.
The museum is smaller than what we expected. The facts about the native people, their culture and their life challenges.
Had lunch. Nice place for lunch and a visit. Beautiful building. Worth a visit. Lots of information, displays, artifacts.
Very nice small size museum with very good quality exhibits. We spent 2 hours here self learning about the native and their culture as well as the animals they hunts.
It's a small place compared to big city museums but it still contained lots of information about Yellowknife & life up north. Worth a visit while I'm town!
A beautiful building with multiple rooms that gives the visitor an overview of the people, resources, geology and development of the NWT
I enjoyed this museum. It has displays that are put together very nicely. I enjoyed reading about the early history of the area.
Super interesting to learn about the local culture. The exhibits were beautiful and well maintained!

New building. Well-done exhibits. Learned a lot about the mineral and animal wealth of the region. Also exhibits on the people, their culture and their language, but did not have enough time to do that justice.
The center is a great place to find out more about the city. Be aware it opens only between 11 am to 2:30 pm.
it is a beautiful museum located in central Yellowknife. The staff are great, the displays top notch, and informative to boot! A definite must see!

The museum is relatively small but has exhibitions of the region and its inhabitants and explorers. Very nice. I very much enjoyed the exhibit about the Norther cultures and diverse adaptions to the different food sources - brilliant. Although the caribou seem to struggle for
Thus has an abundance of arts and culture. Very broad range of colonial history with mining. Wonderful representation of the Norths culture, people, plants and wildlife.

It's awesome place to get some introduction about NWT. I like all the exhibits; the animals look real and the information is thorough. I highly recommend this place for family with children. The best thing is free admission.

Didn't expect we could see so much at this museum. There are lots of interesting, informative display and exhibits depicting the history of the aboriginal and the Northern Territories. Can't ask for more from this free admission museum. Highly recommend to family with young
We recently held a reception at this venue, and it was beautiful. The staff were friendly, helpful, and receptive; the art displays were incredibly well set up and filled with emotion.

This museum is a very well done tribute to life in Northern Canada. They have a wide range of displays featuring a number of different aspects of the history and development of the north and Yellowknife specifically. I was very pleased how they gave very significant and

The museum is free with some neat exhibits. I loved the native bead word on display. There are also some cool pieces from the history of air travel to the north. Worth the time and a nice reprieve from the cold.

A very fun and educational way to spend 2-3 hours. You learn a lot about the history of the place and some interesting artifacts. Being from the lower 48 US, it was interesting to see how humanity found ways to survive and thrive in one of the harshest climates on earth. The
We toured this amazing facility while on our tour of Yellowknife this past August. It is amazing. Informative. Depicts a true picture of our north. A must see.
It's a very nice, well organized and informative museum. It covers local history, native culture. I learnt a lot
This place is free admission, and they have free tours on Wed/Fri/Sat at 11:45AM. It was sufficient to walk through the museum without a tour; the displays were quite informative and interactive.

Nice small museum for Yellowknife district. Lots of local display and information. A very quiet and comfortable place to spend an hour or two in the afternoon. Staffs are friendly and local artists on location to show off their talents.
Visiting the museum is a must if you want to explore the Northeast Territories. There are many precious exhibits. It is also a good education centre.
Excellent exhibits and very educational. While there make time to dine in the Museum Café - the food is delicious.
Excellent overview of the culture, people, and natural attributes of the Territiores! It is well worth a visit to see and 'experience the development of the North

My wife and I walked up the paved 3km Flame Lake trail to this prominent building sitting at the north end. It opened at 10:30AM and was free to enter. After noting the restrooms on the entry floor we walked up to the cafe and noted its restroom. From here we walked down the
There's a lot to see and do in this place. History. Artifacts and information. We have enjoyed and stayed a few hours in this center.

Well done museum with exhibits on mining, aboriginal settlement, and others. The aviation exhibit is excellent with a short film showing how aviation opened up the NWT and highlighting the pioneer spirit. There's a children's section for active play.

This is a must for anyone visiting Yellowknife. You need to allot a few hours to appreciate the displays. The centre gives you a comprehensive view of the land, peoples, and the animals, prehistoric and present day of the Northwest Territories.

Arrived and had many many allergy questions, staff was very helpful and knowledgable. Had an amazing lunch, it was awesome, very generous servings. Nice and bright area to eat. Staff is wonderful!!!!! Thank-you. Continued on with viewing the museum and as usual very

Interesting architecture. Beautiful location. Nice display of local artifacts, regional animals (stuffed) and demonstration videos add to the experience. There were some very nice art installations: large stone carvings and paintings - my residential school experience. Very

The building is clean, bright, and interesting. Great for families with young children. The play area for kids never disappoints. The Museum Cafe serves great food too, but wish they were open on Sunday when we went back.

they really need to advertise this museum differently. we went there and LOVED it there is fabulous displays and interesting exhibits , natural history lovers will enjoy the visit and anyone interested in northern history from expedition, fur trading and arts. a very worth

When I heard that there wasn't an admission fee, I worried that it would not be all that nice. The folks at the visitor's center said it was worth going to, and it did not disapoint! Cool history facts, and they talk about how the natives used each animal that they hunted! some

We spent a good portion of a morning here. The exhibits are wonderful. I loved the sculptures. There is a ton of information in a small building. You definitely get an education on Yellowknife and surrounding area as well as the people of the North. It is a beautiful location

We came to Yellowknife with the sole purpose of aurora viewing. Hence, we woke up late, found a place to walk a bit, then have our dinner and prepare for the night. With this in mind, the centre would be a good place to learn about the history of Yellowknife, including the

This is one of the best Museums we have been to! The detail of information is incredible! You walk away having a new appreciation of life in the north! The security is over zealous in the rules of not touching (which I firmly believe in)even if you point close they will be on
Lots of information about the formation of Yellowknife and the opening up of the North West Territories.
We were fortunate enough today to be part of a guided tour of the museum... A not to miss experience. The displays, the narrative, so well done. A 1 hr well worth while. Thank you.

The quality of the displays, dioramas, videos and information provided here are excellent. I wish we had more time to stay but were pressed to make a flight. Ideally you'd have 1.5 hours to spend here. There is so much to see and watch, very educational and well done. And

First of all, I am not a museum person. But my sister insisted that I should give it a try. Well, it was definitely worth the time. Not only was the exhibit interesting, it was free and you can get lots of suovenirs for free also. I got the cd which shows the city of

The history of this area as well as the flora and fauna of this magnificent area as well as it's rich history are all on display here. From mining (geology) to aviation this museum has numerous informative exhibits which shouldn't be missed. The dioramas of various mammals and
My husband and I really enjoyed the time we spent here. Our tour guide Jean was so knowledgeable and interesting and he was very willing to answer the many, many questions I asked during the tour!

one of my friends lives in Yellowknife and said, Let's go to the museum for lunch. I was so absolutely taken by this place. The food was amazingly well done. The menu choices were amazing. it tid not surprise me to see the place fill up by noon with customers wanting to eat.

What an interesting place to wander about. We had personal tour and came away with a lot more knowledge for the area. The café was also good and our tour guide an expert in his field. He didn't rush us and tried to answer all our questions. The best part of this tour you would

Had an excellent tour this morning at the Prince of Wales Museum. Not only was the museum very interesting but our tour guide Mike was fantastic. Best tour I have been on in my life as it was very interactive and informative.

This museum was very interesting and informative. The interactive activities were awesome. I loved the moose hide tanning demonstrations and the spear throwing was so much fun! Mike was an amazing tour guide, best one I've ever had!! thanks mike!
Learn about the history of the land and the people of NWT. See art exhibits and eat at the cafe. A great half day experience - time well spent.

Usually you have to go to London U.K. or Washington D.C. to be able to explore museums for free but low and behold this fantastic northern museum is free of charge. It has some real interesting exhibits and definitely deserves an hour or more to view them all. I was really

Quite a range of exhibits that give a nice overview of life and history in NWT. Great for families on a budget and there is a kids interactive area. Our daughter and friend were able to a scavenger hunt throughout the museum which helped keep them involved.

This museum has stunning architecture, much like the legislative building. The arches made the place feel so airy. The cafeteria served excellent food. As for the displays- there was a wonderful carver being featured. I am afraid the museum displays were overshadowed by the

Liked the way the museum's collections were set up, and even though we are older and don't have small children, it was nice to see what an effort had been put into making a fantastic play area with costumes and houses to explore.
Beautiful displays of first nations art, way of life, and wildlife and history. Cafe was also very good.
An amazing display of early life in the Territories, wildlife, Mining, transportation, art and culture. Exhibits are well displayed with good explanations. Not to be missed.

Stopped to get info on what our options were in Yellowknife. The staff were excellent, helpful, friendly. Cute stuff to look at and buy. A cross between a museum and gift shop. Lots of brochures. Overall great info and a recommended stop early in your trip

I combined the visitors centre, the legislative Assembly and the Museum in a morning tour/activity and it was great! A beautiful collection of northern history, artifacts and art laid out in a beautiful building and best of all - free! My favourite price! Various displays
Didn't have much time, but it was worth the visit to learn more about the history of NWT. Beautiful exhibits and very comfy chairs!
The museum provides a good overview of the Northwest Territories. There is a terrific play area for preschoolers that fits in with the theme of the museum. The cafe is opened Monday-Friday.

This museum is awesome..there are many great displays featuring wildlife and the ways of northern cultures. The children's play area is fantastic as it gives kids a fun way to experience the museum. There is also a great cafe.
Great family spot with a nice cafe to eat in! Lots to see and its Free! Fun scavenger hunt for the kids and tons to see
There is no charge to visit this museum and it has truly outstanding exhibits. The giant moose hide boat and the video describing how it was made are worth the trip alone!
Nice setting！ excellent location...we can visit there from the bus routing. We got off the bus # B route and off by the supermarket. Then we walked to The visitor center…

Great little museum! Went on the 10:30 free tour with Brian and he was fantastic! Very knowledgable across all area's of exhibits plus much more! Would highly recommend taking a few hours to check this little gem out.
Great displays and wonderful tour guide. Each display was so informative. Liked the film about the moose skin boat.
A great stop in Yellowknife. Has interesting exhibits with lots to learn about the City. Free to the public.
We found the entire museum to be very informative...the cafeteria was such a great place to have lunch.
Was good! Adding life experience to your diary and memorable history of northern life style of the pass.
A must visit when in YK. great location easily walkable or bikeable to. Impressive displays, you really get to understand life in the north
the exhibition is good. we learned a lot about aboriginal history in Yellowknife. there is a coat rack beside the entrance, so visitors don't need to hold the heave down coat during the tour.
Amazing place to visit our history and our land. It's FREE so take in all the beautiful memories and pictures you can take.

A wonderful museum filled with interesting exhibits that tell the history of the NTW and the aboriginal people. Also, yo can learn about the native animals that live or once lived in the area. The museum has a wonderful cafe with fantastic food, so I suggest you plan your visit
This museum had history of Yellowknife and the people who lived there first, information about local animals, and they even had art from a local artist! Loved it!
Best Museum in town. Should take about an hour to do. Short walk from the Explorer Hotel. 10 Minute walk from downtown. Stop at the Northern Frontier Visitors Centre enroute

Very interesting way to learn about the area you are visitng. Try to arrive for lunch at the Museum Cafe (open from 11-2) which is very good. A great way to pass a couple of hours during the day time of a Yellowknife winter
We had a small gap of time between checking out of our hotel and our flights home so we stopped by for a quick look. So glad we did. The galleries present history in the most interesting fashion.
Lots of interesting exhibits and history to explore! Well worth a visit to learn more about Yellowknife and the NW Territories history.

This museum is free, but it's a good idea to bring money to donate because they have put so much into it. It is a great way to learn about the areas history. They also have a café that is not always open, but the manager there is so friendly. We thoroughly appreciate the time we

The museum is a nice little gem that presents several distinct and nicely set-up areas. There are exhibits on local geology and mining (gold ore doesn't look like gold!), the town's history, the ice-age biology of the area (complete with some awesome models of mammoth and

Provides a nice sampling of life 'up North' for a GREAT price (by donation). Leisurely, informative, but not overwhelming. You can spend an hour, or two, depending how much time you have. We loved the visiting exhibit of incredible sculptures by the artist, Abraham Anghik
great informative place, you can find a lot historic information, original peaces. There is also restaurant that everybody recommended, but i did not try (I had already other plans).
Educational, informative & cultural. Not to be missed while visiting Yellowknife .Excellent showvcase of the place. Just across Explorer hotel.

Not only was the museum interesting and informative of the culture but the food was outstanding! The only complaint was that my bison burger was a little fishy. Other than that I highly recommend this place!
Nice please to look at the Aboriginal culture. Interactive and fun place for family with kids. I had a great time there.

This is a must stop place for all tourists to visit. Not only are the displays excellent, but the museum is free. The special section for children would keep them busy for quite some time. Once you have finished viewing the displays, you can relax in the café for good coffee

We decided to tour the museum on a rainy day and it didn't disappoint. Lots of really great exhibits that tell the story of the local history with some great stuff for kids including a play area where they could dress up.

The Heritage center is a great place to learn about the culture of Yellowknife, Canada. The displays are professional and there is a section there for the children to learn. I like the art displayed as well s the video of the elk boat. We also had lunch there and it was
Very interesting, wife especially enjoyed the many exhibits and informative informative exhibit explanations. The building moose hide canoe video was interesting.
We were here on business, so it was nice to see some local culture. This museum is a wealth of artifacts and exhibits. I'm so glad we took a couple hours out to visit. It was worth it.

Great collections and well planned out museum. Looks very clean and new. Loved that there's a "treasure hunt for the kids" while they go through-look to the right when you first arrive to pick it up. When done, the kids get a small price from the info desk for completing it.
Great displays of wild animals, people's cultures and history in the north west territory. Restaurant provides good food and nice views.
Very attractive building in a beautiful setting. Well laid out and organised giving a good overview of the history and culture of this vast region.

I was recommended to stop in and check this place out, and it really was worth the stop. You get to learn about the culture of the First Nations, and see some cool artifacts and learn some history. Definitely worth going to see if you're already in Yellowknife.

After the aurora this was the highlight of our stay in Yellowknife. The exhibits are of very high quality and very informative. The art was amazing. The bison stew was outstanding. A must-see attraction.
I was told by the one person that I knew in Yellowknife that the museum was a must-see an i was not disappointed - beautiful facility and collections
Surely feel that it' not just museum without dedication. Good place for everyone even child, and there's also TripAdvisor's 3rd graded restaurant - museum cafe!
If you like museums give this one a go. Great place to learn all about the NWT and Yellowknife in particular. We really enjoyed it. They also have a wonderful cafe where you can get lunch.

This museum is a must see, preferably early in your trip. You'll learn the history of the region and see historical items. Just an hour or so is all you need to get a better understanding of the area.
We originally came here for their excellent lunches and thoroughly enjoyed all the exhibits. Beautiful building and great resource for the community.
Call in for lunch then check out the exhibits. I'ts a short walk from most hotels and quite the experience walking through the -25 degree cold to get there.

This is an excellent place to learn for free about the area, both Yellowknife and Northwest Territories. The place is very well organized. It has amazing displays: wildlife, historical, mining, etc. It has both static and interactive, multimedia displays. I learned a lot about

If you're into museums and stuff like that, it would be really nice to visit the heritage center. It's really close to the visitor center, so consider visiting them altogether(along with legislative assembly building maybe).
If you come to Yellowknife it worth visiting here for sure! It has a great display of local culture and artist.

A great place to spend a quiet afternoon learning about Canadian history and the history of Yellowknife. The most interesting parts, I found, were about the Native and Western interactions and horrible treatment of the native peoples that unfortunately continues to this day. I
a very informative and cosy museum. a good walk from the town to the museum to admire the winter view around.
Very nice facility with some neat exhibits. It primarily focuses on the aboriginal culture. I would have like to see more exhibits on the mining history and white exploration of the area.

We visited this museum during our trip to Yellowknife. The museum itself is not large, but displays the history of Northern exploration, indigenous people, and wild animals. It is a nice place to visit.
Lots of displays including polar bears.... Very informative! It's close to the Legislative assesbly building, walking distance!
Wonderful facility, amazing carvings currently in the feature gallery, but that is a temporary exhibit. Terrific presentation in various media.
We were killing time between meetings in downtown Yellowknife. Its a lovely space, lots of interesting things to look at. Good summary of the YK area.
Beautifully laid out, lots of interesting items to do with history, culture, wildlife, settlements, geography. Definitely spend an hour or two here.
Very informative with interactive displays. Great way to spend an hour or two. Kids would enjoy the animal displays I'm sure.

I wish more museums were like this. It wasn't pretentious but a welcoming, interesting and interactive chance to learn more about Yellowknife, it's people and their history. I really enjoy that it seemed lots of the exhibits were donated and came with personal stories. This

The PWHC is a must see for both visitors and residents alike. You learn all about the people and the culture of the North. There are also special displays and Fun Sunday events. Lunch at the museum cafe is also a great option
Always wonderful service and food! Handy to the exhibits so you can take a well deserved break. The Chef has daily creations and the price is right!
Great information from the staff about the different trails and things to see. Don't forget to get your photo with the sign at the "line"
This place is worthwhile visiting. The museum provides you with an interesting walk through of the history of the North West Territory's history. Only downside was that the canteen was very messy.
A thoroughly pleasant experience, giving a lot of information on the north which I had not learned in school. Also, it is a family-friendly centre, with hands-on experiences for children.
We found this to be a fabulous museum. A lot of history, culture & art work. One of the exhibits was closed but still plenty to see.
very informative about the history of Canada NW region, free admission ! recommend to at least spend 1 to 2 hours here
Admission is free. A wonderful place to see more of the Northern Heritage. Well organized and nice setup.
Beautiful informative little museum. The biggest surprise was the fantastic restaurant. I had an excellent lunch......could be one of the best in town
Fantastic place - well executed and informative exhibits. Great cafe. Easy to get to from downtown Yellowknife. Near City Hall and a pretty park right on the water.
A surprisingly thorough museum for being so far north. Excellent exhibits, including rotating ones featuring local artists.

This free museum is incredible. We spent about 2 hours there and could have spent another 2. Information on the area's history, wildlife, and residents, plus some sculpture and art (when we visited in 9/2015).
Did a full tour of exhibits which were very informative and the building structure is amazing itself. a really good feeling in there. Had two excellent meals there.

The displays are very thoughtful, interactive and presented in a fun way. There's not a huge amount to look at (you can do the whole museum in an hour) but it gives a great insight into northern lifestyle and has a fun area for kids to play in. I don't have any kids but I would

Oh my gosh, what an amazing place! It took a couple of hours to go through and it really held our interest. I would happily go back. Not a place to miss! For a place as small as Yellowknife, they should be proud of this amazing site!
Don't miss this when you are in Yellowknife. A nice display of the northern heritage and history. There is a fun interactive section for kids too.

The museum is quite compact but very interesting. It is wonderful to learn about the traditional way of living in the Northern hemisphere. Some displays are hands on, others come with a clear oral description. A great place for young and old. No entrance fee- very friendly
Free, interesting, educational. I didn't have a lot of time so my visit was a little rushed but I still had time to enjoy it and learn a lot about the area.

This is a wonderful museum and it is free (admission by donation). I like history and the archives of the Northwest Territories are here. I wish I had the time when I was there to delve into those. I like history and I am particular interested in things like what once took place

Free admission. Donations accepted. Small compared to other big city museums, but good information. Kids enjoyed the visit. Able to do scavenger hunt and received some postcards at the end of the visit. Learned a few things about the North. Try their Cafe. Excellent food

This very small museum has some excellent exhibits highlighting the natural history of the north and the people who share the land with the wildlife. Excellent dioramas. When we were there, we had the privilege of seeing a special exhibit by a renowned Inuit artist Abraham

Wonderful place to visit. Take a tour if you can. It seems that few do, so we had a private tour but that was kindly tailored to our interests. Don't miss the Last Moose Boat Exhibit and movie - very well done. We loved the porcupine quilling demonstration, and the restaurant

Visit the archives and ask how they are funded. It is alarming to see the federal government is not supporting this valuable service. We are losing our history. However, the centre itself is a well run, organized facility. Wonderful northern information. Enjoyed the pilot

As a bed and Breakfast owner I hear from tourist their thoughts about the museum on an going bases. All the guests comment on how modern it is, how informative it is and how well kept the displays are. And those who have made return visits comment on the fact the displays are

Has donation system with no set fee to get in. Some great info on local & regional history. Obvious pride in the exhibits. Apparently what is on display changes but what they did have was great. Nice 'What I Saw' photo gallery with an information blurb by the photographer.
Great displays, interesting mix of natural, cultural and indigenous history. Highly recommended. Also has a great cafetereria
This is a great place to bring children. I have been here many times in summer and in winter. The path through the trees from the Visitor Centre is pleasant.
Well worth taking the time to tour through the Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre. The room with the sculptures is phenomenal - we were really glad we visited the centre.

Beautiful architectural building on a lake. Exhibits are informative and it really gives you a good idea of the culture and history of YK. A Metis weaver, Ria was demonstrating her art on the day I visited.
Very informative and entertaining. Free guided tour is a great way to get the most of the visit. The only problem is the limited parking space.
Lots of neat exhibits of animals, art, and culture. We spent an hour, but you could easily spend two or more. No gift shop, so you have to go to the visitor's center for that.
We were expecting more culture when we planned our trip to Yellowknife. So when we went to the museum it was nice to experience culture, history and the northern life.

This museum was great! Free entrance to the museum which is great since Yellowknife is so expensive. The exhibits were fantastic and interactive. Highly recommend. The museum cafe we stopped to have a coffee and dessert- also worth doing (cheap).
Loved the beautiful building its self and the wonderful displays of life in the north. A Most excellent gallery of stone carvings. Very interesting very worth a visit!

By donation. Several amazing exhibits, including that of the Steppe Bison. It was buried in permafrost for more than 13,000 years, so when it came out, it still had some skin, flesh and hair. Professional interpretive panels explain this animal and compares to modern bison.
Theres some pretty interesting stuff here but wasn't blown away. I was in and out in just over 30 minutes and that was enough. I heard the food here is really good, but a Pepsi runs you 3$...

This is a very interesting place with all sorts of exhibits covering a wide range of Yellowknife/NWT history and life. It is well worth the visit even if you only have a short amount of time to walk through. Art, sculptures, videos, a moose skin canoe, mining, aviation, winter
It is a must visit when you are in Yellowknife. The exhibits are one of a kind and very well presented.
A great spot to start your visit to Yelloknife. This spot has the info you need to plan your visit plus lots of historical information about the area.

I enjoyed seeing the exhibits and learning about northern heritage. Admission is free (donations accepted) and there is a café that is open for lunch. Museum is a short walk from town, near the Frame Lake Trail.

The Centre is centrally located on Frame Lake within a few minutes walk of downtown. It has great information about the human and natural history of the area. My favourite was the exhibition of the old planes and snow machines. Highly recommended for all ages. Great value too as

I visited the PWNHC on three occasions: for lunch, for a lovely musical performance, and to see the museum's exhibits. All three events were high quality. Chef Chris runs a marvelous restaurant with exquisite food, and Table for Five - in a spectacular setting - was an
The dioramas were excellent, the food in the cafeteria was spectacular and the art on display was incredible. Don't miss a visit here

This is a very nicely set up museum. Suitable for people who just want to take a quick look and those who want to linger and get a better understanding of the area, its culture and community. Wide range of exhibits covering topics such as traditional life, economy, settlement
This museum is well laid out and the exhibits are easy to view and read about the information. Would be great for families and all ages. The animal exhibits are amazing !
Visited the centre to see the work of Abraham Ruben and was not disappointed. Excellent sculptures. It was worth the visit
This museum is amazing...... Don't miss it! There is something for everyone. Right now you can experience the works of a world class carver.

This is a small but very interesting museum to learn about northern life and culture, with many interesting photos, a few pieces of painting, and a small collection of artifacts. But to me the most enjoyable parts are the exhibition of sculptures by Inuvialuit Sculptor Abraham

This museum is on the Frame Lake trail. They have beautiful audiovisual diorama of northern animals and also northern communities and how they survived. It's not a big museum but there's a lot of information and fun for adults and children alike. There's currently an exhibit by

What a great place to discover the North's heritage, kid friendly. Amazing displays. Unique exhibits. Wonderful little café. A great place to bring visitors from out of town. Or just to spend the afternoon with the grandkids.

This is a must see for visitors to Yellowknife. The exhibits are fascinating and the sense of history of the area is well told in stories and exhibits. The staff there were very helpful because it was first time there and I wasn't sure where to go. A morning well spent!

Amazing and well thought thru displays, exhibits and information. Beautiful building nestled in awesome surroundings by the lake. THe whole experience is well worth repeating. And- it's the best place to eat in Yellowknife- hands down!! The menu is always varied- extremely
The heritage centre was really interesting. We learned a lot about life this far north. Most definitely worth a visit. Admission is free.
Informative. Plenty of models and speciemens of wild native animals. Worth spending more time in this quality museum.
A nice compact museum highlighting select aboriginals items - historical, embroidery and art display.

I went there together with 3 tourists who happened to be staying in my hotel shortly before they left for their flights. As I returned to the hotel together with them in a rush, I only had a cursory viewing of the major exhibits there which include specimens of foxes, polar

We loved this very interesting museum in Yellowknife and I spent a significant amount of time absorbing the extensive information on the history and cultures that inhabit it. This was an absolute highlight if you're after some local historical insight!

This museum is compact but very informative and a great introduction to the area - would only take you an hour or so to go through it. I had lunch at the cafe there which is a great place to eat on its own. Definitely a go to attaction while visiting Yellowknife

An treasure in Yellowknife. Friendly accommodating and helpful staff, complete with professional exhibits, a comfortable layout, informative exhibits and a great way to learn about the NWT. If you have a few hour layover at the airport - it's a 5 minute taxi ride and well worth

My friend and I went there and incidentally, there was an aurora presentation. We sat in and gained more knowledge about aurora. Very interesting. Then we walked around the entire museum. I really enjoyed the presentation and the flow of the display in various sections.

A great museum with easy to access information on the environment and peoples of the North. We like the special/temporary displays too. There is always something more to learn when we come to this museum.
The Centre had a variety of Cultural and artistic works with many photos and paintings. It was not so big but well arranged and informative.

While the building itself is well worth a visit, the restaurant is the best kept local secret in town. The restaurant is only open from 11:00 to 3:00 and gets very busy around noon so plan accordingly. We went there four times on a six day trip (it was closed on the week-end)
I like the sample polar bear，other animal。 i like the plane and other machine。 My friend took pictures even in TP and snow mobile。 If there was aboriginal music or video about them will be perfect
it doesn´t take long to go through, but it is very informative and great displayed. worth every second spent.

A compact and well put together facility with oodles of interesting things to see and it's all by donation for the entry fee. We thoroughly enjoyed two hours in the facility. Great place to take kids.
Gorgeous museum which is very informative and with extremely well done displays. Really helps one to understand the history of Yellowknife. Really enjoyed touring it!

Shockingly great exhibits and information at this place. Very cool location and building also. There was a VERY special event called Walking With Our Sisters here that was all about the MANY missing and murdered aboriginal women across Canada. Very well down, brought respect,
worth to go! you can know more abt yellowknife and the local how to live in previous day. there is funny n informative
A wonderful place. The staff are kind and very well informed about local history and the area. Definitely worth taking the time to visit.
Visited this centre with our family, great to spend an hour or so. Very good broad information. Great for kids. Very warm and welcoming.
A small museum near Frame lake, that show you the history of Yellowknife and with art gallery area. It is worthwhile to spend some time here to know about the city you visiting
If you have only 24 hours and must do something, then sure visit the heritage centre. In and out in about 20 minutes.

Enjoyed the whole centre. It gives you a good idea of the animals and what life was like in this part of Canada. Also a great showcase for northern artists. Had a great showing of Jennifer Walden while we were visiting.

Great place to see the beauties of the North (nature, animals, culture, rocks, etc..) as well as enjoying a wonderful lunch at the Museum Café. The exhibits are great and make you travel through time or the North. Great presentations and a perfect first thing to do when you

This museum is small but interesting. I helps one understand some of the differences that exist in life in the north, and how it is a combination of new and the traditional.We particularly enjoyed the works of art'

We went last year, in October 2013, and visited for an hour. This year, returning to Yellowknife in September, 2014, we didn't bother. There just wasn't much there. It's worth a quick trip, I don't recall a fee, but don't expect to spend a long time.

A very interesting museum, that provides the visitor with an in depth view of what was, and to some degree is, Canada's last frontier. Unique displays, and a very good restaurant - and to top it off - admission is free. I have visited on 4 occasions and found each visit both

This is a great little museum that is packed with all sorts of things for all ages. It's free. It's interactive and there are hundreds of little tidbits of information. There is a long walking path around Framers Lake near the museum entrance that you can save for another day

I got this confused with the visitor centre on Trip Advisor. See this! It's really nice and your tax dollars have already paid for it. 1500$ Leather chairs are everywhere and almost no one has ever sat in them.
Was very surprised to see how nice this little museum was for being in such a remote area. Definitely worth a visit. Won't take more than an hour two.
Loved this little gem that was unexpected. Different insights into how it all began, how the people lived and some beautiful artwork was displayed

This is a modern facility which packs a number of exhibits into a relatively small space. Every exhibit provides some new insight in the Northwest Territories and it's history. Definitely a must see. Although there is no charge, you can make a donation near the front door.

A really nice little museum that details the history of the area. Awesome opportunity to see samples of the minerals that put Yellowknife on the map and some of the local animals. The best part is that it's FREE!
The interactive displays were fun! Lunch was excellent. Would return for sure! So much to learn here!

Great variety of exhibits and information. The current art exhibit was gorgeous. like everything in the museum, it reflected the NWT land and culture. Beautiful! Plan to visit near lunch time and eat at the Museum Cafe. flected and
art, history, things to touch and travelling exhibits make this a special place to visit... the building is beautiful and has a great cafe... all it needs is a gift shop

If you are interested in seeing some beautiful northern art, this is the place. A historical perspective on the north. The moose-skin canoe is on display(from the movie in the National. Film Board) Make sure you visit the cafe for coffee ans something sweet

Great museum. Lots of cool facts and interactive exhibits... Beautiful artwork as well. I would slot about an hour to two to spend in here.

on our visit to Yellowknife we visited all the touristy places. We were bery impressed with the quality of the museum for such a small city. One highlight was the cafe, excellent lunch at a reasonable price.
What a great place to see!A definite must to explore for anyone visiting Yellowknife.There are so many wonderful things in this Centre.

It is a great place to have fun and understand the history of the area. There was so much to see e.g. lots of artifacts, minerals, dioramas, big canoe made of skins by hands, aboriginal lifestyle, etc. You can also try on their aboriginals' clothing ... really worth to go to

Cafe was wonderful - I've travelled a lot in the north, and was surprised to see so many salads on the menu. I really enjoyed my lunch. That wasn't the highlight, though. The whole facility is great, and nice to walk around. I didn't find the staff overwhelmingly friendly or

Don't miss this museum! It is an essential part of a trip to Yellowknife. Informative, well-laid out, and engaging.

I ordered their lunch special .....white fish with salad, fruit, and rice.That salad had so many items in it and the dressing was excellent. It is a crowded place. Many people ordered the ribeye sandwich......a popular order.

We didn't know about this place before our trip, but what a gem! The museum is free (donations welcome) and has exhibits on everything from nature, to mining to first nations. My 6 year old daughter loved it, and so did we!

I am not a museum person per se, but I thoroughly enjoyed myself. You simply must take advantage of this unique setting in the north while you are in Yellowknife. The museum is free and offers fabulous exhibits to keep you interested.

The museum may be small, but it is packed with information on the area. It was interactive...I especially enjoyed creating my own aurora! The lunch was delightful and the chef even came out to talk to us. Very worthwhile to spend some time there to learn about Yellowknife.

We visited this museum in March. It was very interesting, telling us many things about Yelwlowknife history. The little restaurant was nice,a little expensive for lunch but then everything costs more up here in the north. The ginger cookies were amazing.

We particularly enjoyed the environmental exhibits, but it was all good. The restaurant is fabulous and I would recommend it even if you don't go to the museum itself (though I can't imagine why you wouldn't!).
Very knowledgable about life of the indigenous inhabitants , present environment. Specimen exhibited very attractive. A very good place worth to spend an hour or so to visit around.

The animal dioramas and all information that is provided along with it are excellent. We had two hours left hefore we were going to fly back home, and really enjoyed our visit. Nice for kids as well, including a special area where they can dress up, play in a tipi, log cabin,

This was a lovely museum that look absolutely brand new. We spent over 3 hours here and could have spent more had the cafeteria been open. I had heard that they have terrific, inexpensive meals here, but they were all booked up with an entire group of people. The exhibits were
So impressed by the excellent presentations in this museum - loved it all. Great opportunity to learn about this amazing part of Canada. Do plan to visit for a few hours. Thank you NWT!

Super interpretive and gives a great overview of the culture. Kid's area with dress-up parkas and wall tents sees more than its share of adults as well! Grab lunch at the cafe. You won't be disappointed.

I am a resident and visit the museum regularly. A great place to learn about our history and there are always new exhibits. A good play area for kids while adults stroll around. Excellent restaurant that serves lunch and afternoon tea.
It was interesting and informative. The restaurant in the centre was amazing. Large portions, great prices, and, most importantly, GREAT food!!

A few of us out-of-towners and some local colleagues popped in for lunch at the museum (the food at the museum restaurant is VERY good by the way) and we were impressed with the quality of the exhibits. While it's not a massive building, the displays we saw were very well done

This was a very informative center. Lots of exhibits on the natives, animals, minerals and history of the area. A great video on the construction and use of a moose skin canoe. One can easily spend hours there.
The museum is great place to begin your tour of Yellowknife. It will give you a great overview of the local history and the exhibits are quite interesting and authentic.
A small but very nice museum in a small town lacking of tourist attractions beyond the Northern Lights and surrounding nature.
Situated on a short but spectacular lake walk, the museum beautifully presents exhibits and dioramas to show life in the north. This is a must see!

This a a spot that this well worth a visit when in Yellowknife. We encountered a number of different exhibits that provided us with a view of the culture and heritage of this important city in the country's north. Don't miss the films that are available throughout the building
This was a fabulous place to visit. Give yourself lots of time. We learned so much about the people and the history of the north.

Wow...honestly I think I enjoyed this "museum" better than any other I have been in. Extremely interesting, well laid out and lots of interactive displays. I went in twice! The cafe wasn't open when we were there, I bet it would be nice. Well worth the effort, and well worth

Well worth an hour or more for the visiting tourist. Excellent exhibits range from First Nation peoples to natural history to industry of the North. Very well done. No cost. Donation opportunity available. Short walk from city center. Beautiful site. Easy walk from YK center.

I've been in and out of the North for 15 years and there was plenty for me to learn here. I enjoyed the exhibits and the attention to detail. The kids' area was quite good and I especially appreciated the safe boating messaging in that area. Well done!

I don't like most Heritage Centers, but this one has something for everyone. We spent 2 hours just reading, and looking at all the great collect and stories about the area. Well worth the time, and don't forget to donate.

The displays are grand! The staff friendly! The displays change and are very interesting. Count on spending the better part of the day here checking out the displays. The food was great here as well. best mushrooms soup in town in my opinion!

We visited the Heritage Centre the day we were leaving. If we could do it all over again I'd go at the start. Very interesting and informative and great way to better appreciate Yellowknife, it's history and people. Not a great deal of interactive displays or talks, but items on

This is a first rate interesting museum with many Northern novelties to learn about. We also talked to some of the professional staff who were very nice and helpful.
From the beginning of Yellowknife to present day, the center walks you thru the history and growth of the city and surrounding area.

We learned a lot at this museum about the history of First Nation peoples as well as general history about the area. We went the first full day we had here. It is a great introduction to the NWT, especially for people who know little about the history. It only takes about an
This place is good for about one hour of touring. Interesting to hear about the history and different groups of people.

Possibly the most worthwhile setup I have ever seen. We spent about two and a half hours viewing the displays and getting a great picture of how the North "worked". The diaramas were very life-like, especially the polar bear chewing on on a seal! The whole building is so well
Entrance is free with a donation. Very interesting museum, learn about the history of the NWT, culture and wildlife.
Some exhibits weren't arranged as well as they could, but there were some really interesting artifacts, animals, mementos, etc.
Extremely good and informative displays. Some excellent videos that were well worth watching. We spent about 3 hours there. Very rewarding
Didn't expect this free museum will have much, but it is actually quite big of a place with a lot to see! Remember to give a donation before you leave the place!

We had a great time at the Heritage Centre. We spent parts of two days going around this location. Reading the history and looking at the displays and watching the videos was very interesting. We spent 2 rainy afternoons here and got a lot out of it. If you are going to do
I admit im not a museum person but i found the displays very well done and informative. Well laid out and provides an excellent overview of life in the north.

Nice little museum. I liked the displays but they could use more as the displays of the aviation looked light for the rich heritage the bush pilots had in forming the North. There was only one person on duty that I could see and he was watching the front doors, so no-one
We learned a lot about Yellowknife's history and their current industry with diamond drilling - very very interesting! Make sure to stop. Beautiful new building and exhibits are very interesting.
We spent a great morning here on a rainy day learning about Yellowknife and the NWT.

I am proud to say Yellowknife has such an excellent museum for such a small town. If you want to learn about the North, its history, people and culture then go to PWNHC. If that does not interest you, go just to see the full-sized polar bear in the entrance or the bush plane
Loved the displays and information about the north and Yellowknife. They also have art and events that make it worth the visit
some of the sections like northern animals, wildlife photography, northern fairy tales are very good. nice place to spend your free time especially in the winter.

Excellent showcase of what life is like in the north, and the people who were instrumental in shaping its future. Stories and photos are on display showing the way of life and how hard it was to survive in such a brutal land. One of the most interesting displays is a very long
